(Ord. No. 45-16, 12-12-16; Ord. No. 39-17, 7-25-17) 
Sec. 17-68. - Receipts. 
    A mobile food unit vendor shall, on request by the customer, render to the customer, a receipt for the amount charged, either by a mechanically printed receipt or by a specially prepared receipt on which shall be the name of the license holder of the mobile food vending unit, all charges, and the date of transaction. 
(Ord. No. 45-16, 12-12-16; Ord. No. 39-17, 7-25-17) 
Sec. 17-69. - Clean and safe conditions. 
(a)  Every mobile food unit shall ensure that the interior, including the windows, shall be maintained in a clean and safe condition, free of grease, dirt, debris, or other trash. 
(b)  The exterior of the vehicle shall also be maintained in a clean, undamaged condition and present a favorable appearance, including: 
(1)  The body of the vehicle; 
(2)  The paint; 
(3)  All glass; 
(4)  Hubcaps (if installed); 
(5)  Head and tail lights (if applicable); and 
(6)  Grill and bumpers. 
(c)  No person shall smoke within a mobile food unit. 
(Ord. No. 45-16, 12-12-16; Ord. No. 39-17, 7-25-17) 
Sec. 17-70. - Records; reports. 
(a)  Every mobile food unit vendor shall keep accurate records of receipts from operations, and other expenses, capital expenditures, and other such operating information as may be required to comply with reporting income and expenses under the applicable provisions of the City of Henderson Code of Ordinance[s]. Every mobile food unit vendor shall maintain the records containing such information and other dates required by this chapter at a place readily accessible for examination by the city manager or his or her designee. 
(b)  All accidents arising from or in connection with the operation of mobile food unit vendor which result in death or injury to any person, or in damage to any vehicle, or to any property in an amount exceeding the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00) shall be reported by the license holder or driver within five (5) days from the time of occurrence to the chief of police or his or her designee. 
(Ord. No. 45-16, 12-12-16; Ord. No. 39-17, 7-25-17) 
Chapter 18 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 20. 
State Law reference- Home solicitation sales, KRS 367.410 et seq.; subscription sales of printed material, KRS 367.510 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 18-1-18-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOLICITORS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-16. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Goods, wares, merchandise and services shall include, but not by way of limitation, magazines, periodicals, printed matter and advertising space in any publication. 
    Solicitor shall mean any person who shall solicit orders from door-to-door or on any street or public place within the city, or by telephone within the city, for the future delivery of any goods, wares, merchandise or services. 
(Code 1968, §§ 116.01, 116.02) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-17. - Exemptions. 
    This article shall not apply to salesmen selling goods to retail or wholesale stores for resale. Any person who has, and has had for the preceding twelve (12) months, a regular place of business within the city, and any person employed by or soliciting for any person who has, and has had for the preceding twelve (12) months, a regular place of business within the city, shall not be required to register before soliciting orders. 
(Code 1968, § 116.08) 
Sec. 18-18. - Article supplemental to existing ordinances. 
    This article shall be supplemental to all existing ordinances and shall not be construed to effect a repeal of any licensing ordinance now in force. 
(Code 1968, § 116.09) 
Secs. 18-19-18-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGISTRATION 

Sec. 18-26. - Required. 
    No person shall do business as a solicitor without first registering as provided in this division. 
(Code 1968, § 116.02) 
Sec. 18-27. - Application. 
    An applicant for permission to be a solicitor shall complete an application blank provided by the city clerk, which application blank shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, home address and local address, if any, of the applicant; 
(2)  A physical description of the applicant, setting forth the applicant's date of birth, height, weight, color of hair and eyes; 
(3)  (a)  The name and address of the person by whom or through whom orders are to be solicited or cleared, including both the home address and the address of the office or branch out of which the applicant works; 
(b)  A list of each solicitor to include name, address, date of birth and copy of photo I.D. of each one; 
(4)  The nature of the goods, wares, merchandise or services for which orders are to be solicited; 
(5)  A statement as to whether the applicant has been arrested or convicted of any crime and, if so, what; 
(6)  A statement as to the period during which the applicant intends to solicit orders, which shall not extend beyond December 31 of the calendar year during which the application is made. 
(7)  The application must be filed at least five (5) business days before the requested solicitation is to begin. All approved applications will remain valid for a period of thirty (30) days subject to item number (6) above. Applications for renewal of permits must be submitted at least five (5) business days before the expiration of the existing permit. 
(Code 1968, § 116.03; Ord. No. 16-85, 5-14-85; Ord. No. 41-07, 11-27-07; Ord. No. 34-18, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 18-28. - Identification of applicant and soliciting. 
(1)  The applicant, at the time of executing the application blank under section 18-27, shall also submit identification satisfactory to the police department which shall contain a specimen of the applicant's signature. 
(2)  All solicitors or authorized representative shall display a solicitation photo card, provided by the City of Henderson at a cost of twelve dollars ($12.00) to be paid by each solicitor, while soliciting door to door. 
(Code 1968, § 116.04; Ord. No. 41-07, 11-27-07; Ord. No. 34-18, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 18-29. - Approval of application. 
    Upon compliance by the applicant with the provisions of sections 18-27 and 18-28, the police department shall communicate its approval upon the application to the city clerk; provided, however, that the police department shall not be required to grant such approval to any person who shall have been convicted of any felony or misdemeanor or of the violation of this article. 
(Code 1968, § 116.05; Ord. No. 41-07, 11-27-07; Ord. No. 34-18, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 18-30. - Transfer, effect, etc., of credentials. 
    Credentials issued under this division shall be nontransferable and shall entitle the holder thereof, for the period indicated therein, unless revoked, to solicit orders within the city for the purchase of the merchandise specified in the submitted application, provided that the holder shall have their credentials in their possession at all times while soliciting orders and shall exhibit the same at any time upon request by any police officer of the city or any purchaser or prospective purchaser. 
(Code 1968, § 116.06; Ord. No. 34-18, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 18-31. - Registration does not permit entry in privately policed areas. 
    Registration under this division shall not be construed to be a permit to enter privately policed areas. 
(Code 1968, § 116.07) 
Sec. 18-32. - Rules governing approved solicitors. 
    Approved solicitors must observe the following: 
(1)  No solicitations are permitted from sunset to 8:00 a.m. 
(2)  Solicitors shall not, in an effort to further sales, make offensive utterances, gestures or displays, use abusive language to any person or otherwise engage in a course of conduct or repeatedly commit acts which alarm or seriously annoy other persons and serve no legitimate purpose. 
(Ord. No. 16-85, 5-14-85) 
Sec. 18-33. - Revocation and penalties. 
(1)  Any solicitor, including a charitable solicitor, in violation of the rules and regulations set forth in this division shall be subject to having his/her approval for solicitation revoked without refund of any administrative fees which might have been charged. The same shall apply to any business utilizing multiple solicitors. 
(2)  The chief of police, upon determining a violation(s) of the rules and regulations set forth by this division, may order such solicitation approval revoked, without refund of any administrative fee which might have been charged. Any person who feels aggrieved by such determination by the chief of police may, within five (5) days of receipt of the order from the chief of police, appeal that determination to the city manager. The decision of the city manager shall be final. 
(3)  In addition to having his/her approval for solicitation revoked, any person who intentionally violates the rules and regulations set forth in this division shall be guilty of a class A misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 16-85, 5-14-85; Ord. No. 41-07, 11-27-07) 
Secs. 18-34-18-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Solicitation for charitable and civic purposes, KRS 367.650 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-46. - Definition. 
    As used in this article, the term "charitable solicitations campaign" shall mean any course of conduct whereby any person, organization, society, association, corporation or any agent, member or representative thereof (hereafter in this article called "solicitor") shall solicit property or financial assistance of any kind or sell or offer to sell any article, tag, service, emblem, publication, ticket, advertisement, subscription or any thing of value on the plea or representation that such sale or solicitation or the proceeds therefrom are for a charitable, educational, patriotic, religious or philanthropic purpose. 
(Ord. No. 16-75, § 1, 6-10-75) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-47. - Credentials. 
    All solicitors to whom permits have been issued under this article shall furnish proper credentials to their agents and members for such charitable solicitations campaign. Such credentials shall include the name of the permit holder, the date, a statement describing the holder's chief executive officer, and the name and signature of the agent to whom such credentials are issued and the specific period of time during which the agent is authorized to solicit on behalf of the permit holder. The credentials shall also state prominently whether or not the contribution will be tax deductible to the donor. 
(Ord. No. 16-75, § 6, 6-10-75) 
Sec. 18-48. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 34-18, adopted Nov. 13, 2018, repealed former § 18-48 which pertained to unlawful methods, and derived from Ord. No. 16-75, § 10, adopted June 10, 1975. 
Sec. 18-49. - Nonliability of employees. 
    All of the regulations provided for in this article are hereby declared to be governmental and for the benefit of the general public. Any member of the board of commissioners, or any city official or employee, or any person charged with the enforcement of this article, acting for the city in the discharge of his duties, shall not thereby render himself personally liable, and he is hereby relieved from all personal liability for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties. Any suit brought against any such official or employee because of such act performed by him in the enforcement of any provision of this chapter shall be defended by the city attorney until the final adjudication of the proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 16-75, § 9, 6-10-75) 
Secs. 18-50-18-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 18-56. - Required; exemption. 
    It shall be unlawful to conduct any charitable solicitations campaign on the streets or in any public place or by house to house canvass in the city unless the person conducting same and responsible therefor shall first have obtained a permit in compliance with the terms of this article; provided, however, that the provisions hereof shall not apply to any solicitor that has an income tax exemption from the Internal Revenue Service for charitable, religious or educational purposes, when it solicits from its own members or from its own assemblies. 
(Ord. No. 16-75, § 2, 6-10-75; Ord. No. 34-18, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 18-57. - Registration form. 
    Prior to conducting a subject charitable solicitations campaign, or campaigns, a solicitation registration form must be completed in full and filed with the city clerk and the police department not less than three (3) business days prior to initiation of the campaign, or campaigns. A solicitor may utilize the form for more than one subject charitable solicitations campaign except any campaign utilizing a professional agency or professional solicitor, whereby the professional retains at least fifty (50) percent of gross funds raised, shall require a separate registration. Such form shall contain the format as kept on file in the clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 16-75, § 3, 6-10-75; Ord. No. 41-07, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 18-58. - Issuance; fee; term. 
    Upon completion in full of the form and submission thereof prior to the minimum three (3) business day period, and upon payment to the city clerk of a five dollar ($5.00) registration fee, the city clerk shall issue a permit to conduct a charitable solicitations campaign, or campaigns, for the period and in the manner set forth in the submitted form. Such period shall not exceed twelve (12) consecutive months. 
(Ord. No. 16-75, § 4, 6-10-75; Ord. No. 41-07, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 18-59. - Transfer. 
    The permit shall be personal to the solicitor and shall not be assigned or transferred. 
(Ord. No. 16-75, § 5, 6-10-75) 
Sec. 18-60. - Responsibility for acts under permit. 
    The recipient of a permit for a charitable solicitations campaign shall be responsible for the acts of his authorized representatives in connection with such campaign. 
(Ord. No. 16-75, § 7, 6-10-75) 
Sec. 18-61. - Forms and permits as public records. 
    All forms and permits issued under this division shall be public records. 
(Ord. No. 16-75, § 8, 6-10-75) 
Sec. 18-62. - Charitable solicitation bucket shakes. 
(a)  Charitable organizations wishing to use a bucket shake as a means of solicitation must seek and obtain a charitable solicitation permit. 
(b)  No such permit shall be issued unless the charitable organization provides proof that it has in force general liability insurance in the minimum amounts of five hundred thousand dollars/one million dollars ($500,000.00/$1,000,000.00) naming the City of Henderson as an additional insured. 
(c)  No person shall stand or walk upon a road or highway for the purpose of soliciting contributions unless that person is at least eighteen (18) years of age and is wearing a safety vest containing reflective material. 
(d)  Charitable solicitations by bucket shakes shall be limited to the hours of 2:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. on Fridays, 10:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. on Saturdays, and 10:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. on city-celebrated holidays. In no event shall such charitable solicitations be conducted after sunset on any day. 
(e)  The City of Henderson does not have the authority to allow bucket shakes to be conducted on state or federal highways and shall be allowed only at certain specified locations within the city to be designated from time to time by resolution of the board of commissioners. 
(f)  Charitable organizations shall be limited to four (4) solicitation permits for bucket shakes per calendar year. Each permit shall be valid for one (1) day of solicitation. 
(g)  In times of inclement weather, City of Henderson may cancel a bucket shake, and allow the charitable organization to reschedule its bucket shake to another available date. 
(Ord. No. 16-85, 5-14-85; Ord. No. 11-99, § 1, 5-11-99; Ord. No. 34-18, 11-13-18) 
Chapter 19 - PLANNING[1]

(b)  A copy of the city-county comprehensive plan shall at all times be kept in the office of the city clerk.

Chapter 20 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating. relocating, opening, closing, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city saved from repeal, § 1-5(6); any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street within the city saved from repeal, § 1-5(7); airport, Ch. 3; dogs running at large, § 6-24; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; cemeteries, Ch. 8; deposit or storage of refuse on street or sidewalk prohibited, § 14-26; posting on poles, § 16-2; wearing hoods or masks in public places, § 16-5; spitting or expectorating in public places, § 16-6; curfew for minors, § 16-21 et seq.; parks and recreation, Ch. 17; peddlers and solicitors, Ch. 18; planning, Ch. 19; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 22; utilities, Ch. 23; vehicles for hire Ch. 24; waterways, Ch. 25; zoning, App. A; subdivision regulations, App. B; public improvement specifications. App. C. 
State Law reference- Municipal improvements, KRS Ch. 107. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Approval required for obstruction. 
    No person, firm, or corporation shall erect or maintain any obstruction across or upon any street, alley, sidewalk, or public rights-of-way of the city without the consent and written approval of the city manager. For the purposes of this section, obstructions shall include, but not be limited to, any house, fence, wall, building, structure of any kind, or any post, rail, or other fixed object that may in any way obstruct, either totally or partially, any street, alley, sidewalk, or public right-of-way. This section shall not prohibit the planting of trees, shrubs, or other plants provided that vision is not totally or partially blocked at intersections as defined in Section 4.09 of the zoning ordinance of the city. 
    This section shall also not prohibit canopies and building overhangs provided that such canopies and overhangs are attached to a principal building and are not freestanding or require an independent support structure and comply with Section 4.09 of the zoning ordinance of the city. Retaining walls may be permitted pursuant to this section if, in the opinion of the city manager or codes administrator, such retaining wall is necessary to either protect the safety of persons or to preserve private property rights provided that the placement or replacement of any retaining wall or structure is carried out in accordance with Section 4.09 of the zoning ordinance of the city. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation found to be in violation of this section shall be given a written notification of the violation that exists and be given fifteen (15) calendar days to correct any and all violations cited. If the violation continues to exist after the expiration of the notification period, the city may remove the obstructions and may charge the property owner for the number of hours involved in eliminating the obstructions at a charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per hour. The city may, at its option, choose not to remove any obstructions and cause a citation to be issued to the property owner for violating this section of the code with these charges to be heard in Henderson district court. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation given notice pursuant to this section of the code by any official of the city may file an appeal within the fifteen-day time period established in this section with the city manager citing the reason or reasons that this section of the code should not be enforced. The city manager shall issued a final determination in writing to the person, firm, or corporation filing such an appeal, and the decision of the city manager shall be final. 
(Code 1968, § 92.01; Ord. No. 2-73, § 1, 1-17-73; Ord. No. 14-88, 4-26-88; Ord. No. 56-88, 11-8-88) 
Sec. 20-2. - Cellar doors and gratings opening on public ways. 
    No person shall permit his cellar door or cellar way on any public avenue to remain open or permit same or any grating or vault to remain in a dangerous or unsafe condition to passersby. 
(Code 1968, § 92.03) 
Sec. 20-3. - Injury to pavements. 
(a)  No person, without lawful authority, shall dig, break, displace or injure any pavement, curbing or other work on any street, alley or sidewalk, or dig, excavate or fill same in the city. 
(b)  No person, without lawful authority, shall cause a discharge of a concentrated source of water onto the city right-of-way and/or a city, pavement, curbing, alley or sidewalk in such a manner as to cause damage thereto. 
(Code 1968, § 92.02; Ord. No. 10-79, 5-8-79) 
Sec. 20-4. - Reasonable use of streets and sidewalks for loading and unloading. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall prevent the reasonable use of the streets, alleys or sidewalks for the purpose of receiving, shipping or delivering goods or merchandise or other articles for family use. 
(Code 1968, § 92.09) 
Sec. 20-5. - Petition to board of commissioners for greater than ordinary use of streets or sidewalks. 
    Any person desiring any greater use of any street, alley or sidewalk than is provided in this chapter, may petition the city manager for same, and if granted, shall not be subjected to the penalties denominated therein; but such privilege, if granted, shall be temporary and may be revoked at any time in the discretion of the city manager. 
(Code 1968, § 92.10; Ord. No. 08-18, 3-27-18) 
Sec. 20-6. - Closing street or alley without authority. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to close up or fence any public alley or street of the city and for each day's continuance thereafter in so offending after conviction, shall be deemed a separate offense, after notice by city authorities to remove the obstruction. 
(Code 1968, § 92.16) 
Sec. 20-7. - Booths, concessions, carnivals for the sale of merchandise on streets. 
    No person or organization shall erect, maintain or place any carnival, street show, booth, concession or any place of amusement or any stand for the sale of any article of merchandise on any street, right-of-way, avenue or highway of the city, unless the person or organization has obtained a special event permit pursuant to section 17-49, and is in compliance with the terms of their special event permit. 
(Code 1968, § 92.19; Ord. No. 15-13, 5-28-13; Ord. No. 08-18, 3-27-18) 
Sec. 20-8. - House numbering plan. 
(a)  All buildings and houses shall be numbered consistent with the assigned address. 
(b)  The plan for numbering the buildings and houses in the city is as follows: Even numbers shall be placed on the east and south sides of each street, and odd numbers on the west and north sides. Twenty (20) feet shall be allowed to each number and the numbers shall begin from Water Street and proceed east, and from Center Street and proceed north and south. Not more than one hundred (100) numbers shall be used to the block, and each block shall commence with the next succeeding hundred. 
(c)  Building and house numbers or letters shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Minimum three (3) inches in height. 
(2)  Shall be of contrasting colors to the building. 
(3)  Numbers shall be highly visible from the street or driveway on the front of the building. 
(d)  The placement of numbers on residential structures shall be in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  Numbers or letters shall be placed on the side of the building facing the street of address in close proximity to and in the general area of the entrance door in a conspicuous position and at a height which shall be easily visible from the street. 
(2)  The number or letter may be placed over the garage door provided it remains visible from the street. 
(3)  Apartment buildings, hotels and motels shall have either number or letter designations and apartment or room number or letter ranges. 
Examples: 
Building 1, Apts. A-D 
Building A, Apts. 1-4 
(4)  The lot numbers of mobile homes in mobile home parks shall be placed on the ends of the mobile home facing the street or drive. 
(5)  Mobile homes on single lots in areas of the city zoned R-3 shall place the number on the end of the mobile home facing the street, or in the same manner as other single-family residential structures. 
(e)  Street side mail boxes shall be numbered consistent with requirements set forth by the U.S. Postal Service. 
(f)  The placement of numbers or letters on commercial buildings shall be in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  Numbers shall be placed near the entrance door at least five (5) feet above floor level. 
(2)  If the entrance does not face the street on which the building is numbered, building numbers shall be placed on the end of the building facing the numbered street in a conspicuous place, easily visible from the street or driveway. 
(3)  Numbers shall also be placed over the rear door of occupancies located in buildings with a common entrance, such as shopping malls, multi-story buildings, etc. 
(g)  The Henderson City-County Planning Commission is designated as the official agency responsible for assigning new addresses and changing addresses that do not meet the standards as outlined in chapter 20 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1968, §§ 92.17, 92.18; Ord. No. 14-97, § 1, 6-10-97; Ord. No. 38-97, 10-28-97; Ord. No. 6-16, 2-23-16; Ord. No. 08-18, 3-27-18) 
Sec. 20-9. - Encroachment for outdoor dining on public sidewalks. 
(a)  (1)  No person or entity shall place tables or seating for tables for dining (hereinafter collectively "seating") on the public right-of-way, including public sidewalks, (hereinafter "public sidewalks") unless that person first has obtained a permit encroachment for the tables and seating from the city manager or his or her designee (hereafter collectively "city manager") and has had such seating approved by the codes department. The city manager is authorized to promulgate written regulations that define appropriate seating. 
(2)  Encroachment permit for tables and seating shall only be issued to businesses licensed to serve food and/or beverages located in the following areas Riverfront Zone 2 or the Central Business District and with at least ten and one-half (10.5) feet of paved sidewalk directly adjacent to the building. 
(3)  Encroachments for tables and seating may only be permitted in locations on the public right-of-way that are deemed appropriate by the city manager or his/her designee. The city manager may refuse to grant an encroachment that he or she believes may be injurious to the health, safety and well-being of the pedestrians and the general public, causes noncompliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act, blocks or inhibits vehicle sightlines, or creates a public nuisance, as defined by the city's nuisance ordinance. No encroachment shall be issued to an applicant that is not current on his/her/its obligations to the city, including taxes, loans, liens, and unremediated violations of the city building or nuisance codes. 
(b)  The encroachment shall specify the number of tables and chairs and the specific location of the tables and seating. The encroachment shall place the tables and seating only in the areas designated in the encroachment. The applicant shall provide the following to the city manager before qualifying for the issuance of an encroachment: 
(1)  The name of the applicant, including the type of organization, e.g. proprietorship, partnership, corporation, limited liability company, and the person responsible for compliance with this subchapter; 
(2)  The address of the applicant; 
(3)  A map or diagram drawn to scale depicting the number, type and dimensions of tables and seating. The map shall illustrate the width of the sidewalk and specifically identify where the tables and seating or benches will be located; the city will establish permanent marks in the sidewalk to delineate the boundaries of the permit. 
(c)  The following provisions and certifications shall be conditions of any encroachment granted by the city manager: 
(1)  Inclusion of a release and indemnification provision releasing and indemnifying the city from personal injury and property damage liability resulting from the use of the tables and seating and sidewalk; 
(2)  Certification that the applicant will inspect and report to public works in a timely manner any defects in the sidewalk; 
(3)  Certification that the business will clean the right-of-way on which tables and seating are placed, including sidewalks and abutting curbs and gutters, of all litter and debris each night after outdoor service is finished; 
(4)  Certification that the applicant is the owner of the property abutting the sidewalk, or if a lessee of the property, a certification of ownership from the lessee's landlord must be submitted; 
(5)  The business, at its sole expense, shall maintain comprehensive general liability insurance, protecting against all claims for personal injury, death or property damage occurring upon, in or about the premises resulting from the use of occupancy thereof, with a minimum of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) in coverage and limits acceptable to the city for the entire term of the encroachment agreement insurance rated and any extension thereof. The city must be named in this policy as an additional insured entity. Further, if the business serves alcohol, then the business must have liquor liability insurance with a minimum of one million dollars ($1,000,000). The city must also be named in this policy as an additional insured entity. The business shall include copies of all policies of insurance with evidence of the payment of the premiums thereon with his, her or its application. The applicant shall deliver to the city at least ten (10) days prior to the expiration of such policy, evidence that it has been renewed. All policies of insurance carried hereunder shall provide that they cannot be canceled without giving at least ten (10) days prior written notice to the city and shall be written by insurance companies licensed by the Commonwealth of Kentucky and reasonably satisfactory to the city. Any insurance carried by a business on his, her or its own property or for his, her or its own benefit in connection with this section shall contain a clause waiving any claim by the insurance company for subrogation against the city; 
(6)  Business shall ensure that no part of the right-of-way, sidewalk or curb is damaged by his/her/its outdoor seating, including prevention of stains on sidewalks and curbs caused by the seating. Business shall refrain from using any harsh or damaging chemicals to clean any stamped concrete sidewalks or surfaces upon which tables or seating is placed. Business further agrees that any damage caused to a Henderson right-of-way, sidewalk or curb by the business seating will be repaired or repair costs reimbursed by the business; 
(7)  The business shall maintain the right-of-way used for outdoor dining during the winter months (November through March), including cleaning the paved surface, and shall ensure that all seating is removed from the sidewalk during these months when not in use; and 
(8)  Any other information reasonably required by the city manager to properly administer the intent of this subchapter. 
(d)  No alcoholic beverages shall be served or consumed on the public sidewalk, unless the portion of the public sidewalk where the permitted tables and seating are located is included in the "encroached premises" for a business liquor by the drink restaurant, tavern, or dining facility as approved by the city alcoholic beverage control administrator and the state department of alcoholic beverage control or otherwise allowed by law and the encroachment holder enters into a separate encroachment agreement with the city. 
(e)  It shall be the responsibility of the business to maintain the encroached premises in orderly fashion, including requiring that all persons within the business premises behave in an orderly fashion and not generate excessive noise. This requirement shall be strictly enforced. 
(f)  The cost of the encroachment shall be an annual fifty dollars ($50.00) application fee and fifty cents ($0.50) per square foot in the area contained in the encroachment on the public sidewalks. Payment shall be made to the Department of Finance at the City of Henderson by January 1 of each year. Upon issuance of an encroachment agreement by the city and payment of the annual encroachment fee by the business, the business shall be permitted to place tables and seating on the public sidewalks on a continuous basis from April 1 until October 31. Tables and seating may not be placed on public sidewalks on a continuous basis from November 1 until March 31. 
(g)  Business shall not operate sidewalk dining earlier than 7:00 a.m. and all operations in outdoor dining must cease and be vacated by 10:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and 11:00 p.m. Friday and Saturday. 
(h)  Any encroachment issued by the city to allow for placement of tables and seating on the public sidewalks shall not be assigned or transferred to third party without the prior written consent of the city manager. 
(i)  An encroachment may be revoked with thirty (30) days notice for any reason. In such event, the cost of encroachment will be refunded on a prorated basis. 
(j)  An encroachment may be revoked by the city upon seven (7) days' written notice upon a finding by the city manager that the business has violated any terms of this section, the sidewalk dining creates a health/safety risk, has failed to abide by the terms or conditions set forth in the encroachment, or upon a finding by the city manager that the business has violated city ordinances or state or federal law. An encroachment may also be revoked by the city manager if the business establishment has two (2) or more convictions for violating the city's noise control ordinance within a twelve-month period, or the business or an employee of the establishment has been convicted of serving alcohol to a minor. If an encroachment is revoked, the business shall not be eligible to reapply for an encroachment until one (1) year has passed from the date of the encroachment revocation. The business may appeal this revocation to the city board of commissioners within fourteen (14) days of the notice of revocation. If a business fails to appeal an encroachment revocation within the time frame set forth herein, such decision shall not be subject to further review. If an encroachment has been revoked under this section, the business will not be entitled to a refund. 
(Ord. No. 27-13, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 20-10. - Public utility easements. 
(a)  Any area within the City of Henderson designated by deed, plat or otherwise as a public easement, public utility easement, or utility easement, shall grant the city, or any public utility operating in the city, the right to construct, reconstruct, replace, repair, operate and maintain utility facilities, together with appurtenant structures, for use in connection with the transmission and distribution of the respective utility and communication facilities. 
(b)  No person, firm or corporation shall erect any structure, permanent or otherwise, or plant any trees, shrubs or other large vegetation, in a public utility easement, either at the surface or to the sky above, which would interfere with the city's access to the easement area, or which would inhibit the city's ability to perform its necessary work within said easement area, without the consent and written approval of the city manager or his designee. 
(c)  No person, firm or corporation shall excavate within an easement, or change the grade of the real property in the easement area without the consent and written approval of the city manager. 
(d)  Fences and ornamental landscaping (shrubs, small bushes, flower beds, etc) are permitted in public utility easements, with the stipulation that any damage to fences and/or ornamental landscaping necessitated by utility construction, repair, or maintenance activity is at the risk of the property owner. 
(e)  The city and/or its utilities shall not be responsible for repairing and/or replacing any damage done to real or personal property, including, but not limited to, the repair or replacement of trees, shrubs, fences, parking lots, driveways, walls, walkways, pools, patios/decks, sport courts, excessive fill of soil or rock, or structures built, removed and/or destroyed within the easement area by utility construction, repair, or maintenance work in said easement area, regardless of whether an encroachment has been granted or not, and the costs of such repair or replacement is at the risk of the property owner, except as noted in section (f) below. 
(f)  The city and/or its utilities shall only be responsible for repairing and/or replacing any damage done to any driveway, fence or screening that is constructed as a requirement of any local government regulations, including the zoning ordinance, building code, city Code of Ordinances, or other applicable laws. The costs to be borne by the city and/or its utilities for such required elements shall be for basic materials of construction, and shall not include any special surface treatments, aesthetic enhancements, or other features. 
(g)  Requests for approval of encroachment or change of grade within a public right-of-way or public utility easement shall be made by the property owner on forms provided by the city. After review and approval by the utilities serving the property, the city manager may approve or disapprove the application for encroachment on the public right-of-way or public utility easement on a case by case basis. 
(h)  Approval of any encroachment is subject to revocation by the city upon notice to the property owner. By permitting an encroachment into an easement area, the city does not waive any of its rights granted herein and does not obligate itself to pay for repair or replacement of property damaged by utility construction, repair, or maintenance work in said easement area. 
(i)  For purposes of this section, "at the risk of the property owner" is defined to place the burden of all expenses for replacement of non-required constructed elements, special surface treatments, aesthetic enhancements or other features on the person, firm or corporation who owns the property on which the element or elements are located. 
(j)  Where a public utility easement exists, by dedication or prescription, the private property owner (the servient estate) is responsible for maintenance, including but not limited to mowing; removing debris, litter, and yard waste; and maintenance of landscape items such as flowers, trees and shrubs. The city utilities (Henderson Municipal Gas, Henderson Water Utility, or Henderson Municipal Power and Light) may at their discretion trim, cut, trim or remove any tree or shrub that occupies any public utility easement and interferes in any way with the utility facilities in said easement. 
(Ord. No. 29-14, Exh. A, 8-26-14) 
Sec. 20-11. - Sale of merchandise on sidewalk in the central business district. 
(a)  Any merchant who regularly engages in the retail sales of merchandise in the central business district shall have the right to display and sell merchandise regularly sold by such merchant on any city sidewalk which adjoins the place of business of such merchant without the necessity of procuring a permit which is otherwise required pursuant to Section 20-1. Provided, however, such activities shall not extend into any adjoining street or thoroughfare. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the foregoing authorization, any merchant who displays and sells merchandise on city sidewalks in the central business district shall comply with the following regulations: 
(1)  The display and sale of merchandise on any city sidewalk shall only take place during the business hours of the merchant, and all merchandise, including any display apparatus, and any equipment or other related apparatus, together with any trash and debris, shall be removed from the city sidewalk immediately upon the close of business. 
(2)  The display and sale of merchandise on any city sidewalk shall be done in an orderly and reasonable manner, next to the business, and extend no more than three (3) feet onto the sidewalk and must leave a minimum of four and one-half (41/2) feet of unobstructed sidewalk (pavers next to the curb are not to be counted as part of the measurement of unobstructed sidewalk) and shall at no time obstruct the public's reasonable access upon and across any city sidewalk or right-of-way, nor shall it in any manner be adverse to any necessary emergency or safety access. 
(3)  Any merchant who displays and sells merchandise on any city sidewalk shall regularly inspect the city sidewalk which adjoins the place of business of the merchant for defects or hazardous conditions, and, should any defect or hazardous condition be found, the merchant shall immediately notify the city manager and the public works department. Merchants shall refrain from displaying or selling merchandise on any city sidewalk during inclement weather. 
(4)  The business, at its sole expense, shall maintain comprehensive general liability insurance, protecting against all claims for personal injury, death or property damage occurring upon, in or about the premises resulting from the use of occupancy thereof, with a minimum of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) in coverage from an insurance company with an A rating. The city must be named in this policy as an additional insured entity. The merchant shall also indemnify the city and save it harmless from any claim or cause of action which may be asserted by any person against the city by reason of the merchant's use and operation upon the city sidewalk, or by reason of the merchant's violation of any provision as set forth herein. Before a merchant displays any merchandise on city sidewalks, they must produce their insurance to the city manager for his/her approval and sign the city's indemnification form. 
(Ord. No. 36-16, 12-6-16) 
Secs. 20-12-20-23. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 30-14, Exh. A, adopted Aug. 26, 2014, amended art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. II, §§ 20-24-20-26, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the 1968 Code, §§ 92.12-92.14; and Ord. No. 22-76, § 1, adopted Nov. 9, 1976. 

Sec. 20-24. - Approval required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall make any changes, alterations or cuts, nor in any other way violate the existing condition of the sidewalks, curbs, gutters and streets or alleys of the city, without first having filled out necessary forms and having obtained a permit from the city manager or his designee. In emergency situations, a permit may be obtained on the next business day after such change, alteration or cut begins. Permit application fees and inspection fees may be charged as established by the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 30-14, Exh. A, 8-26-14) 
Sec. 20-25. - City to keep records, GIS data, etc. 
    The city engineering department, the public works department, or other designee of the city manager, shall make and keep an accurate record of all excavation permits showing the work permitted thereunder, and shall have any such connections, or extensions made a part of and shown on the record drawings or in the geographic information system of the city. The city shall also maintain, subject to public inspection all information related to details of the sanitary sewer and stormwater systems, water mains, gas mains and any other underground public service units that may be installed in, for or by the city or under any such permit. 
(Ord. No. 30-14, Exh. A, 8-26-14) 
Sec. 20-26. - Responsibility for cost; replacing, rebuilding after excavation; utility locates (811). 
    Any person, firm or corporation excavating, digging or performing trenchless construction, shall be responsible for the cost of, and after having completed such work, be required to replace and rebuild that portion of the public streets, public alleys or public sidewalks, damaged or removed, in such a manner that it will be in a condition as good as it was prior to the issuing of the permit for such work. Any person, firm or corporation performing work covered by this chapter shall be responsible for calling Kentucky 811 (utility locates) prior to performing any work. It shall further be the duty of any person, firm or corporation performing such work to backfill any and all excavations in such a manner as will meet the approval of the city. 
(Ord. No. 30-14, Exh. A, 8-26-14) 
Sec. 20-27. - Bond and insurance for contractors. 
    Before a permit is issued under this article, any person, firm or corporation performing excavation or backfill within any public right-of-way, or making changes, alterations or cuts on any public street, sidewalk, curb, gutter or public alley as an independent contractor shall file a bond or letter or credit in the penal sum of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) payable to the city, conditioned upon the faithful observance by the licensee of all applicable ordinances and regulations of the city pertaining to disturbance or reconstruction of said public street, sidewalk, curb, gutter or alley. Any person, firm or corporation performing such work shall also present proof of insurance, in amounts set by the city manager, for liability, property damage and personal injury, and naming the City of Henderson as an additional insured. 
(Ord. No. 30-14, Exh. A, 8-26-14) 
Sec. 20-28. - Indemnification of city. 
    Any person, firm or corporation obtaining a permit under Section 20-24 shall bind itself to protect, indemnify and hold harmless the city, its elected officials, its appointed officials, its employees, and the citizens thereof, from any damage or liability that may arise on account of any infringement by the person, firm or corporation on the rights of any other person, firm or corporation. It shall also protect and indemnify the city, its elected officials, its appointed officials, its employees and the citizens thereof from all damage and liability, including all costs, and attorneys' fees, by reason of any other act of such person, firm or corporation. 
(Ord. No. 30-14, Exh. A, 8-26-14) 
Secs. 20-29-20-36. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TREES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 31-99, adopted Sept. 14, 1999, completely repealed the provisions of former §§ 20-37-20-46 and replaced them with the similar provisions of §§ 20-37-20-43 as currently set out herein. Former §§ 20-37-20-46 derived from Ord. No. 39-95, §§ 2-11 adopted Sept. 12, 1995. 

Sec. 20-37. - Designation of a city tree board. 
    The parks and recreation board shall serve as the city tree board. 
(Ord. No. 31-99, 9-14-99) 
Sec. 20-38. - Definitions. 
    Tree. Any woody plant which meets any one of the following criteria: 
(1)  Has a trunk four (4) inches or more in diameter at one (1) foot above the ground; or as further defined by the tree board. 
(2)  Is of a horticultural variety or is highly ornamental (such as dogwood, redbud, crab apple, sourwood, flowering cherry or peach, southern magnolia, holly, etc.) and has a trunk diameter of three (3) inches or more at one (1) foot above the ground, or has attained a capable stature of flowering and reproducing. 
(Ord. No. 31-99, 9-14-99) 
Sec. 20-39. - Functions and powers; advisory. 
(a)  It shall be the function of the board to advocate the preservation of trees within the City of Henderson and to encourage tree planting and tree replacement in the community. 
(b)  When requested by the board of commissioners or city manager, the board shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and recommend upon any special matter or question coming within the scope of its work. 
(Ord. No. 31-99, 9-14-99) 
Sec. 20-40. - Public tree care. 
(a)  The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs, or parts thereof within the lines of all streets, lanes, circles, squares, and public grounds, as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. 
(b)  Private persons, businesses or organizations may be allowed to plant trees within the right-of-way of any city street or upon other city property, provided such plantings may only be done with the written permission of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 31-99, 9-14-99) 
Sec. 20-41. - Pruning and clearance. 
    The city shall have the right to prune, cut, clear, or remove any tree, shrub, bush or flower on public or private property which overhangs any street, right-of-way or easement, or to prune, cut, clear or remove any tree, shrub, bush or flower on public or private property when such interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a street light, or interferes with the visibility of any traffic control device or sign, or interferes with pedestrian travel, or interferes with the safe line of sight along any street or roadway, or which is injurious or a potential threat to sewers, electrical power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other public improvements. 
    When it becomes necessary to prune, cut, clear or remove any tree, shrub, bush or flower pursuant to this section, the city will attempt to minimize the amount of pruning, cutting, clearance and removal of trees necessary to accomplish the safety objective undertaken. 
(Ord. No. 31-99, 9-14-99) 
Sec. 20-42. - Unlawful to cut. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cut, top, prune, trim, or remove any tree on any city greenbelt, right-of-way, park, or other city property without the written permission of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 31-99, 9-14-99) 
Sec. 20-43. - Dead or diseased. 
    The city shall have the right to identify any dead or diseased trees on public property within the city, when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city. 
(Ord. No. 31-99, 9-14-99) 
Chapter 21 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Assessments by office of county tax commissioner. 
(a)  The city does hereby elect to use the annual county assessment for property situated within the city as a basis of ad valorem tax levies. 
(b)  The appropriation ordinance to be passed for each fiscal year shall provide for the payment to the office of the county tax commissioner the fee prescribed by KRS 132.285 in order to compensate such office for its services in providing the annual assessment for city property. 
(Ord. No. 37-69, §§ 1, 2, 12-10-69)

State Law reference- Utility gross receipts license tax for schools, KRS 160.613 et seq. 

Sec. 21-18. - Levy. 
    The utility gross receipts license tax for schools of three (3) percent of the gross receipts derived from the furnishing, within the city, of telephonic and telegraphic communications services, electric power, water, and natural, artificial and mixed gas, as authorized by KRS 160.613 and as requested by the board of education is hereby levied on the furnishing of all such utilities within the city, which are billed on or after September 1, 1975, to consumers residing in the Henderson Independent School District. 
(Ord. No. 27-75, 7-8-75)
