April 2001 ..... 5.00 
May 2001 ..... 3.33 
June 2001 ..... 1.67 
(b)  Persons sixty-five (65) years of age or older and persons who possess valid handicapped license plates or sticker identification issued by the Commonwealth of Kentucky shall pay a license fee per motor vehicle in accordance with the following schedule: 
July 2000 ..... $ 14.00 
August 2000 ..... 12.83 
September 2000 ..... 11.67 
October 2000 ..... 10.50 
November 2000 ..... 9.33 
December 2000 ..... 8.17 
January 2001 ..... 7.00 
February 2001 ..... 5.83 
March 2001 ..... 4.67 
April 2001 ..... 3.50 
May 2001 ..... 2.33 
June 2001 ..... 1.17 
(c)  This article shall not apply to motor vehicles owned and operated within the corporate limits of the city by licensed new and used dealers for the sole purpose of the sale thereof, nor those vehicles exempt as a matter of law. 
(d)  Disabled veterans who have been issued a motor vehicle by the Veteran's Administration under the provisions of Title 38, Section 1901, of the United States Code or any other public law that may be passed by the Congress of the United States shall be exempt from the requirements of this article and shall be provided a motor vehicle license at no charge. 
(e)  The amounts charged for motor vehicle license fees as set forth above shall be effective for the months denoted and shall terminate effective July 1, 2001. 
(Ord. No. 14-93, 6-8-93; Ord. No. 32-95, 7-11-95; Ord. No. 18-00, 6-13-00) 
Sec. 21-72. - Presumptions. 
    For the purpose of enforcement of this article, it shall be presumed that the owner or operator of any vehicle licensed within the City of Henderson intends to utilize their motor vehicle upon the public streets within the city and is the party responsible for the purchase of such city sticker. 
(Ord. No. 14-93, 6-8-93) 
Sec. 21-73. - Due date. 
(a)  The license fee imposed by this article shall be due and payable on the same date as the state vehicle license as each license year becomes due. 
(b)  Any person becoming subject to the provisions of this article shall be allowed a period of thirty (30) days from the date of becoming subject thereto in which to obtain such license without penalty or fine. 
(Ord. No. 14-93, 6-8-93) 
Sec. 21-74. - Issuance; term. 
    Upon payment of license fee herein provided, a license shall be issued by the city for each motor vehicle required to be registered under the provisions of this article, which license shall expire June 30, 2001. 
(Ord. No. 14-93, 6-8-93; Ord. No. 18-00, 6-13-00) 
Sec. 21-75. - Registration stickers. 
    The city shall provide registration stickers with numbers corresponding to the numbers of the license issued hereunder, which registration stickers shall be at all times displayed conspicuously upon the lower corner of the driver side of the front windshield of any motor vehicle so licensed, and it shall be unlawful for any person subject to the provisions of this article to operate or cause to be operated such motor vehicle within the corporate limits of the city without proper display of such registration sticker. 
(Ord. No. 14-93, 6-8-93) 
Sec. 21-76. - Transfer. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person subject to the provisions of this article to transfer or cause to be transferred from one motor vehicle to another any license or registration sticker issued pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Whenever any motor vehicle for which a license has been issued changes ownership, the transferor shall cause such license sticker to be removed from the motor vehicle and mutilated. On the transfer of another motor vehicle to the transferor, and on proof of such mutilating, which may be in the form of any affidavit of the transferor, the city shall cause a license to be issued and provide such transferor with a registration sticker for such vehicle without charge for the remainder of the license year for which license was originally issued. 
(Ord. No. 14-93, 6-8-93) 
Sec. 21-77. - Use of funds. 
    All money derived from the license fees under the provisions of this article shall be placed in a separate account of the city, and such sums shall be used and expended in each license year for the construction, alteration, maintenance and repair of the streets, roads, sidewalks and public ways within the city, and such other structures and mechanisms as may be required in the control and regulation of motor vehicles and pedestrian travel within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 14-93, 6-8-93) 
Sec. 21-78. - No refunds. 
    There shall be no refunds made by the city by reason of the payment of any license fee imposed by this article. 
(Ord. No. 14-93, 6-8-93) 
Sec. 21-79. - Severability clause. 
    It shall be considered that it is the intent of the City of Henderson, in enacting this ordinance, that if any part of it be held unconstitutional the remaining parts shall remain in force, unless the ordinance provides otherwise, or unless the remaining parts are so essentially and inseparably connected with and dependent upon the unconstitutional part that it is apparent that the city would not have enacted the remaining parts without the unconstitutional part, or unless the remaining parts, standing alone, are incomplete and incapable of being executed in accordance with the intent of the city. 
(Ord. No. 14-93, 6-8-93) 
Sec. 21-80. - Penalties. 
    Any person, business, firm or corporation found to be in violation of sections 21-71-21-80, which is known and commonly referred to as the motor vehicle license fee for the City of Henderson, Kentucky under chapter 21 of the Code of Ordinances, shall be required to pay a twenty-five dollar administrative charge to the department of finance of the city, and shall further be required to purchase the motor vehicle license sticker. 
    Any person, business, firm or corporation found to be in violation of section 21-75 of the motor vehicle license fee shall be fined not more than ten dollars ($10.00) and required to fully comply with the said motor vehicle license fee and article provision. 
    The Henderson city police, their designated representative, and/or director of finance shall issue a violation notice containing the necessary information of said violation as prescribed by the chief of the police department or director of finance. 
    Any person, business, firm or corporation found to be in violation of chapter 21 of the Code of Ordinances shall pay the said twenty-five dollar administrative charge within ten (10) days of the issuance of the said violation. 
    Any person, business, firm or corporation found to be in violation of chapter 21 of the Code of Ordinances shall be required to purchase the motor vehicle license sticker prior to being able to pay the twenty-five-dollar administrative charge to the department of finance of the city. 
    Failure to pay the said administrative fine will result in the issuance of a summons to the Henderson district court for violation of the provisions of chapter 21 of the Code of Ordinances, in compliance with the penalties established by the Kentucky Revised Statutes and the Henderson Code of Ordinances (Ord. No. 31-88, 6-22-88). 
    Noncompliance. Any employer who fails to comply with section 21-71, or any other provision of this article, shall be subject to a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), and shall further be required to comply with the information requirement contained in section 21-71. 
(Ord. No. 14-93, 6-8-93) 
Secs. 21-81-21-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PROPERTY ASSESSMENT AND REASSESSMENT MORATORIUMS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-94, adopted April 26, 1994, amended the Code by adding an Art. IV, §§ 21-56-21-67. In order to avoid duplication of section numbers, the editor has redesignated the provisions of Ord. No. 17-94 as Art. VI, §§ 21-91-21-102, as herein set out. 
Cross reference- Assessments by office of county tax commissioner, § 21-1; central business district, App. A, Art. XX. 

Sec. 21-91. - Moratorium program established. 
    There is hereby established a program for the granting of property assessment or reassessment moratoriums for qualifying units of real property located in the following zoning districts in the City of Henderson as shown on the city's official zoning map: 
(a)  General Business (GB). 
(b)  Highway Commercial ("HC"). 
(c)  Residential Office (RO). 
(d)  Neighborhood Business (NB). 
(e)  Riverfront (RF-2). 
(f)  Audubon Commercial District (ACD). 
(g)  Gateway Zone District #1 (GZD#1). 
(h)  Henderson Innovative Planning District (HIP). 
    For a building to qualify in the above-stated districts, it must be twenty-five (25) years or older and must have as its primary purpose and use the operation of a commercial business enterprise. 
    Real property located in the Central Business zoning district is eligible for property assessments or reassessments under this chapter. To qualify, the building must be twenty-five (25) years or older and must have its primary purpose either the use of the operation of a commercial business enterprise or for use as a residential property. 
(Ord. No. 17-94, 4-26-94; Ord. No. 03-12, 1-24-12; Ord. No. 04-15, 3-24-15; Ord. No. 32-18, 10-23-18) 
Sec. 21-92. - Administering agencies. 
    The administering agencies for this moratorium program shall be the appropriate legislative body, or the Henderson city commission, or a body to be designated by them. 
(Ord. No. 17-94, 4-26-94) 
Sec. 21-93. - Moratoriums to be limited to five-year period. 
    All moratoriums shall be for a period of five (5) years, and each shall become effective on the assessment date next following the issuance of the moratorium certificate. 
(Ord. No. 17-94, 4-26-94) 
Sec. 21-94. - Applications for moratorium certificates. 
    Applications shall be made to the administering agency for a property assessment or reassessment moratorium certificate as follows: 
(1)  The application shall be on a form prescribed by the department of revenue and shall be filed in the manner prescribed by the administering agency. 
(2)  The application shall be filed with the administering agency thirty (30) days before commencing the restoration. 
(3)  The application shall contain the following: 
a.  A general description of the property; 
b.  A general description of its proposed use; 
c.  The general nature and extent of restoration, repair, rehabilitation or stabilization to be undertaken; 
d.  A time schedule for undertaking and completing the project; and 
e.  If the property is a commercial facility, the application shall also contain a descriptive list of the fixed building equipment which will be a part of the facility and a statement of the economic advantages expected from the moratorium, including expected construction employment. 
(Ord. No. 17-94, 4-26-94) 
Sec. 21-95. - Assessment reassessment of property by property administrator on receipt of application. 
    The property valuation administrator and the administering agency shall maintain a record of all applications for a property assessment or reassessment moratorium. The PVA shall assess or reassess the property within thirty (30) days of receipt of the application. This assessment shall be the value for which taxes are not to be raised for five (5) years. 
(Ord. No. 17-94, 4-26-94) 
Sec. 21-96. - Time limitation for completion of improvement; by applicant extensions. 
    The applicant shall have two (2) years in which to complete the improvements unless granted an extension by the administering agency and the appropriate legislative body. In no case shall the application be extended beyond two (2) additional years. This provision shall not preclude normal reassessment of the property. 
(Ord. No. 17-94, 4-26-94) 
Sec. 21-97. - Inactive applications rendered void; when. 
    Any application not acted upon by the applicant shall become void two (2) years from the date of application and shall be purged from the files of the property valuation administrator and the administering agency. 
(Ord. No. 17-94, 4-26-94) 
Sec. 21-98. - Assessment of property following expiration, cancellation, etc. of moratorium. 
    On the assessment date next following the expiration, cancellation or revocation of an assessment or reassessment moratorium, property shall be assessed on the basis of its full fair cash value. 
(Ord. No. 17-94, 4-26-94) 
Sec. 21-99. - Verification of completed project prerequisite to issuance of moratorium certificate. 
    The applicant shall notify the administering agency when the project is complete, and the administering agency shall then conduct an onsite inspection of the property for purposes of verifying improvements. Only after the project is complete and the improvements verified shall the moratorium certificate be issued by the administering agency. 
(Ord. No. 17-94, 4-26-94) 
Sec. 21-100. - Transfer or assignment of moratorium certificate to new owner or lessee. 
    An assessment or reassessment moratorium certificate may be transferred or assigned by the holder of the certificate to a new owner or lessee of the property. 
(Ord. No. 17-94, 4-26-94) 
Sec. 21-101. - Eligibility for subsequent moratorium certification; reapplication. 
    Any property granted an assessment or reassessment moratorium may be eligible for a subsequent moratorium certification provided that reapplication be made no sooner than three (3) years following the expiration of the original moratorium. 
(Ord. No. 17-94, 4-26-94) 
Sec. 21-102. - Definitions for interpreting this article. 
    Definitions for interpreting this article shall be those outlined in KRS Chapter 99 relating to property assessment and reassessment moratoriums. Repair, rehabilitation, restoration or stabilization of property as used therein shall include the demolition of an existing structure and the construction of a new structure if it is more economical to do so given the condition of the existing structure, and the applicant provides a comparative cost analysis in the moratorium application justifying such demolition and reconstruction. In such cases, the assessment by the PVA for the purpose of establishing the value for the moratorium shall be based on the existing structure prior to demolition. 
(Ord. No. 17-94, 4-26-94; Ord. No. 03-12, 1-24-12) 
Secs. 21-103-21-109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TRANSIENT ROOM TAX 

Sec. 21-110. - Tax imposed. 
    To provide funds for the operation of the tourist commission, there is hereby continued a transient room tax of three (3) percent on the gross rent received for the occupancy of a suite, room or rooms charged by motor courts, motels, hotels, inns or similar businesses in the City of Henderson. 
(Ord. No. 14-18, 6-12-18) 
Sec. 21-111. - Term. 
    The transient room tax shall remain in force and effect perpetually from the date of its enactment unless terminated by ordinance of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 14-18, 6-12-18) 
Sec. 21-112. - Collection; filing of returns; penalty. 
(a)  Motor courts, motels, hotels, inns or similar businesses shall collect the transient room tax and shall pay the same to the City of Henderson Tax Collector. Said taxes shall be paid by the collecting party no later than thirty (30) days following the month in which said taxes were collected. Each collecting agent shall file a return in duplicate on a form provided for said purpose, along with a copy of the collecting agent's Kentucky sales tax return for the same period. 
(b)  Failure to properly complete same and to pay said taxes within thirty (30) days following the month during which the taxes were collected shall result in a penalty of six (6) percent of the total tax due, plus interest at the rate of twelve (12) percent per annum, and shall subject the collecting agent to such civil and criminal remedies as are available in the Kentucky Revised Statutes. In the event a civil action is filed to collect outstanding taxes, penalties and interest and attorney's fees may be assessed and recovered as costs in an amount not to exceed the judgment amount awarded for the taxes, penalties and interest, subject to proof by the attorney to the court that the award of attorney's fees is reasonable based upon the actual work performed. All payments shall be applied to any penalty and interest then to taxes owed. 
(c)  The City of Henderson's Finance Director is hereby designated as the City of Henderson Tax Collector for transient room tax under this article. The executive director of the tourist commission shall assist the finance director for the City of Henderson in determining and identifying any business and/or entity subject to the transient room tax under this article. 
(Ord. No. 14-18, 6-12-18) 
Sec. 21-113. - Use of funds. 
    All transient room tax monies not expended by the commission during any fiscal year shall be used to make a part of the commission's budget for the next fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 14-18, 6-12-18) 
Sec. 21-114. - Audit. 
    The Henderson County Tourist Commission is subject to audit of the room tax funds upon the request of the board of commissioners of the City of Henderson. 
(Ord. No. 14-18, 6-12-18) 
Chapter 22 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance prescribing traffic regulations for specific locations, prescribing through streets, parking limitations, parking prohibitions, one-way traffic, limitations on loads of vehicles or loading zones or dealing with parking meters, parking meter zones or flow of traffic generally, not inconsistent with this code saved from repeal, § 1-5(13); ambulances, Ch. 5; junked vehicles and junkyards, § 15-21 et seq.; offenses, Ch. 16; planning, Ch. 19; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 20; motor vehicle license tax, § 21-71 et seq.; vehicles for hire, Ch. 24. 
State Law reference- Licensing of motor vehicles, operators and trailers, KRS Ch. 186; automated motor vehicle registration KRS Ch. 186A; financial responsibility law, KRS Ch. 187; nonresident motorists, service of process, KRS Ch. 188; traffic regulations and vehicle equipment and storage, KRS Ch. 189; motor vehicle sales, KRS Ch. 190. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases hereinafter enumerated shall for the purposes of this chapter have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section. Definitions set forth in the Kentucky Revised Statutes, as amended from time to time, shall prevail except where those herein set forth are different therefrom. 
    Alley means any passage or way for public use which serves as a secondary or rear entrance to property. 
    Bicycle means any device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having two (2) tandem wheels, either of which is over twenty (20) inches in diameter and including any device generally recognized as a bicycle though equipped with two (2) front and two (2) rear wheels. 
    City manager means the city manager, acting either individually or by and through the city engineer, the police chief or the police department. 
    Curb means the boundary of that portion of the street used for vehicles, whether marked by curbstones or not. 
    Double parking means the stopping, standing or parking of any vehicle upon the main traveled portion of any street or public way in any manner other than that specified in section 22-36 except in a case of real emergency. 
    Loading zone means the roadway space adjacent to the curb reserved exclusively for the loading and unloading by vehicles of passengers and property. 
    Parking means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not. 
    Pedestrian means any person afoot. 
    Police official means an officer of the police department or any municipal officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations. 
    Private road or driveway means every way or place in private ownership and used for vehicular travel by the owner and others having express or implied permission from the owner. 
    Right-of-way means the privilege of the immediate use of the roadway. 
    Roadway means the portion of a street improvement, designed or indicated for vehicular travel. 
    Safety zone means the area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and which is protected or is so marked by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times while set apart as a safety zone. 
    Street or highway means the entire width between property lines of every way or place, of whatever nature, when any part thereof is open to the use of the public, for the purpose of vehicular traffic. 
    Through street or highway means every street or highway or portion thereof, at the entrance to which vehicular traffic from intersecting streets or highways is required by law to stop before entering or crossing the same. 
    Traffic means pedestrian, ridden or herded animals, vehicles and other conveyances, whether singly or together, while using any street for purpose of travel. 
(Code 1968, § 70.02) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-2. - Authority of police and fire department officials. 
(a)  The officers of the police department, and of such officers as are assigned by the chief of police, shall enforce all street traffic laws of this city and all of the state vehicle laws applicable to street traffic in this city. 
(b)  Officers of the police department and all such officers as are assigned by the chief of police are hereby authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand or signal in conformity with traffic laws, provided that in the event of a fire or other emergency, or to expedite traffic, or to safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police department may direct traffic as conditions may require notwithstanding the provisions of the traffic laws. 
(c)  Officers of the fire department, when at the scene of a fire, may direct or assist the police in directing traffic in the immediate vicinity. 
(Code 1968, § 70.07) 
Sec. 22-3. - Obedience to police and fire department officials. 
    No person shall willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a police officer or fire department official. 
(Code 1968, § 70.08) 
Sec. 22-4. - City streets designated as links of state or federal highway. 
    Whenever the state secretary of transportation, by authority of KRS 177.042 to 177.047 designates any streets or portions thereof, including viaducts and bridges, as connecting links of state or federal maintained highways, or necessary feeder streets thereto and thereby undertakes the future maintenance, repair, construction or reconstruction of such streets, bridges or viaducts in the manner provided by the aforesaid statutes, the mayor is hereby expressly authorized, instructed and directed to enter into any and all contracts and agreements with the department of highways necessary to carry out the purposes and provisions of the statutes. 
(Code 1968, § 70.03) 
Sec. 22-5. - Traffic-control devices. 
(a)  The city manager shall cause to be erected and maintained traffic-control signs, signals and devices when and as required under this chapter and any traffic ordinances of this city to make effective the provisions of this chapter and such ordinances, and may place and maintain such additional traffic-control devices as he may deem necessary to regulate traffic under this chapter or under state law or to guide or warn traffic. 
(b)  All traffic-control signs, signals and devices existing on the effective date of this Code are hereby ratified and approved and shall be considered as having been lawfully installed. 
(Code 1968, § 70.12) 
Sec. 22-6. - Display of unauthorized signs, signals or markings. 
    No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any highway any unauthorized sign, signal, marking or device which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic-control device or railroad sign or signal, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any official traffic-control device or any railroad sign or signal, and no person shall place or maintain, nor shall any public authority permit, upon any highway any traffic sign or signal bearing thereon any commercial advertising. This shall not be deemed to prohibit the erection upon private property adjacent to highways of signs giving useful directional information and of a type that cannot be mistaken for official signs. Every such prohibited sign, signal or marking is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and the authorities having jurisdiction over the highways are hereby empowered to remove the same or cause it to be removed without notice. 
(Code 1968, § 70.21) 
Sec. 22-7. - Designations of crosswalks, safety zones and traffic lanes. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized to: 
(1)  Designate and maintain by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where there is danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway and at such other places as he may deem necessary; 
(2)  Establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians; 
(3)  To mark lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as he may deem advisable, consistent with the traffic ordinances of this city. 
(Code 1968, § 70.15) 
Sec. 22-8. - Zones of quiet. 
(a)  Hospitals. The city manager shall have the authority to establish a zone of quiet upon any street in or around hospitals located within the corporate limits of the city, and shall place at a conspicuous place or places on or near the street signs sufficiently large to give notice to drivers of vehicles that they are in a zone of quiet. 
(b)  Temporary zones of quiet. The city manager shall have the authority to establish a temporary zone of quiet upon a street where a person is seriously ill, if requested to do so by the written statement of at least one registered physician certifying as to its necessity. Such temporary zone of quiet shall embrace all territory within one hundred (100) feet of the building occupied by the parties named in the request of the physician. The temporary zone of quiet and any other zone of quiet declared by any ordinance of this city shall be designated by placing at a conspicuous place in the street a sign or marking bearing the words "Quiet Zone". 
(Code 1968, § 70.19) 
Sec. 22-9. - Play streets. 
(a)  The city manager shall have authority to declare any street or part thereof a "play street" and to place appropriate signs or devices in the roadway indicating and helping to protect the same. 
(b)  Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating any street or part thereof as a "play street," no person shall drive a vehicle upon any such street or portion thereof, unless he has business or resides within such closed area, and then any such driver shall exercise the greatest care in driving upon any such street or portion thereof. 
(Code 1968, § 70.18) 
Sec. 22-10. - Use of coasters, roller skates and similar devices. 
(a)  No person upon roller skates, or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle, or similar device shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a street at a crosswalk, and when so crossing, such person shall be granted all of the rights and be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. This subsection (a) shall not apply to the use of skateboards, and this subsection (a) shall not apply on any street while set aside as a play street as authorized by this chapter. 
(b)  The use of skateboards on streets, sidewalks, and rights-of-way located in the City of Henderson, Kentucky, including property owned by the City of Henderson, Kentucky, is hereby prohibited. Skateboarding shall only be permitted in designated areas which are properly designed for that activity, on appropriate facilities designed for the said use. This subsection (b) does not govern or regulate the use of skateboards on private property located in the City of Henderson, Kentucky. 
(Code 1968, § 70.06; Ord. No. 27-88, 6-14-88) 
Sec. 22-11. - Speed limits. 
(a)  No operator of a vehicle upon a street or highway within the corporate limits of the city shall drive at a greater speed than is reasonable and prudent, having regard for the traffic and for the condition and use of the street or highway. 
(b)  No operator of a vehicle upon the streets or highways of the city shall exceed a speed of thirty (30) miles per hour, except that on streets and highways maintained by the state the speed limit shall be thirty-five (35) miles per hour. 
(c)  Drivers of vehicles when operating within a properly marked school zone shall operate their vehicles in a reasonable and prudent manner at all times and shall not exceed a speed of twenty (20) miles per hour while in such zones; provided, however, that where schools zones are located along streets or highways maintained by the state the speed limit shall be twenty-five (25) miles per hour. 
(d)  Whenever the city manager shall determine upon the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation that any speed hereinabove set forth is greater or less than is reasonably safe under the conditions found to exist at any location within the corporate limits of the city, he may establish by official order a reasonable and safe speed limit at such locations which shall be effective at all times; provided, however, that where speed limits different from those specified in subsections (b) and (c) are thus established, the change shall not become effective as to state maintained streets or highways unless and until approved by official order of the state secretary of transportation. 
(Code 1968, § 71.02; Ord. No. 51-94, 9-27-94) 
State Law reference- Speed, KRS 189.390. 
Sec. 22-12. - Stop when traffic obstructed. 
    No operator shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic control indication to proceed. 
(Code 1968, § 71.06) 
Sec. 22-13. - Driving to avoid traffic signals. 
    The operator of a vehicle shall not undertake to avoid the effect of a traffic signal light or other traffic-control device by leaving the street or passing through any filling station or other vacant space or corner. 
(Code 1968, § 71.10) 
Sec. 22-14. - Vehicles shall not be driven on a sidewalk. 
    The operator of a vehicle shall not drive within any sidewalk area except at a permanent or temporary driveway or alley crossing. 
(Code 1968, § 71.20) 
Sec. 22-15. - Streets newly laid or under repair. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle over or across any newly made pavement or into any area of a roadway blocked off for repairs at which there is a temporary barrier, a person or a sign indicating no passage. 
(Code 1968, § 71.11) 
Sec. 22-16. - Parades and processions. 
(a)  No procession or parade shall occupy, march or proceed along any street except in accordance with the permission of the city manager. 
(b)  No operator of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion and when such vehicles are conspicuously designated as required in this section. 
(c)  All funeral processions shall move upon and through the public streets of the city as speedily as possible, with due regard to custom and traffic conditions, and shall be led or piloted by the undertaker or his duly authorized agent or representative, and there shall be displayed in a conspicuous manner on the vehicle leading or piloting such procession a purple flag of substantial material eight (8) inches wide by twenty (20) inches long with the word "Funeral" running lengthwise in the center thereof. Such flag shall be displayed unfurled and on a standard by the lead or pilot car from the starting point of such procession until arrival at the cemetery or at the city limits. 
(d)  Every automobile in a funeral procession, including the lead or pilot car, shall have its headlights burning continuously from the starting point of such procession until arrival at the cemetery or the city limits. 
(e)  When a traffic signal changes to red while a funeral procession is passing the same, the procession shall continue moving and cross traffic shall stop until the entire procession has passed such signal. 
(Code 1968, §§ 71.15, 71.19) 
Sec. 22-17. - Riding on the outside of vehicle. 
(a)  No person shall ride on a running board, hood, fender or other outside part of any vehicle, provided, however, that this section shall not apply to employees riding on the back step of a truck in the necessary or proper course of his employment. 
(b)  No owner or operator of a vehicle shall permit any person to ride on the outside thereof in violation of subsection (a). 
(Code 1968, § 71.17) 
Sec. 22-18. - Clinging to moving vehicles. 
    No person riding upon a bicycle, motorcycle, coaster, sled, roller skates or any toy vehicle shall attach the same or himself to any moving vehicle upon any roadway. 
(Code 1968, § 71.22) 
Sec. 22-19. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article for which no other penalty is provided shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than twenty dollars ($20.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. 
(Code 1968, § 70.99) 
State Law reference- Similar penalty, KRS 189.990. 
Sec. 22-20. - Lights on police department emergency vehicles. 
    At the discretion of the chief of police, emergency vehicles used by the police department may be equipped with either blue rotating, flashing or oscillating lights or with a combination of red and blue rotating, flashing or oscillating lights. The type of equipment utilized will be based on the use of individual vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 40-84, § 1, 12.19-84) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 40-84, § 1, adopted Dec. 19, 1984, did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion herein as § 22-20 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 22-21. - Roller skating, inline skating, rollerblading, skateboarding and bicycling prohibited from certain areas. 
(a)  No person shall at any time, use, operate or ride upon roller skates, inline skates, rollerblades, skateboards, bicycles or other similar devices in Central Park in the city or upon the sidewalks adjacent to and within said park, nor shall any person at any time use, operate or ride upon roller skates, inline skates, rollerblades, skateboards, bicycles or other similar devices on the riverwalk located in the city. 
(b)  No person shall use, operate or ride upon roller skates, inline skates, rollerblades, skateboards, bicycles or other similar devices in parks other than Central Park located within the city and/or upon streets and sidewalks in the city during the times special community events are occurring within said parks and/or on city streets and sidewalks, unless a person is using, operating or riding upon such devices as a part of his or her participation in such event. "Special community events" include, but are not limited to, the Lion's Club Tri-Fest, Blue Grass in the Park, W.C. Handy Blues Festival, the Christmas parade and other parades, and such other similar events as may be determined by the city manager to be special community events. 
(c)  The provisions of subsection (a) and (b) do not apply to the riding of bicycles by police department personnel for law enforcement purposes. 
(d)  No person shall at any time use any bench, table, garbage can, or other property belonging to the city as a ramp or jump for roller skating, inline skating, rollerblading, skateboarding or bicycling at any location within the city. 
(e)  Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall be required to pay an administrative charge to the department of finance of the city in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) within ten (10) days from the date of the violation. Failure to pay said administrative charge within said ten (10) day period shall result in appropriate action being taken in the Henderson district court for the violation of this section. 
(f)  The City of Henderson Police Department shall issue the violation notices containing the necessary information of said violation as prescribed by the chief of police and the director of finance. 
(Ord. No. 33-95, 7-25-95) 
Cross reference- Use of coasters, roller skates and similar devices, § 22-10. 
Secs. 22-22-22-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-36. - Parallel parking, permitted in either direction; exceptions. 
    No operator of any vehicle shall stop, stand or park such vehicle (except in a case of a real emergency, or in compliance with a provision of this article or when directed by a police officer, traffic sign or signal) in any manner other than within twelve (12) inches of and parallel with the curb, except when angle parking is in effect; provided, however, that on state and federal highways and in the central business district, vehicles shall park parallel to the curb or edge of the roadway in the direction of authorized traffic movement, with the right-hand wheels within twelve (12) inches of the right-hand curb or as close as practicable to the right edge of the right-hand shoulder, except when angle parking is in effect. For this section, the central business district shall be defined as an area bounded by Fourth Street on the north, Washington Street on the south, Green Street on the east, and Water Street on the west. 
(Code 1968, § 72.04; Ord. No. 45-00, 11-28-00) 
Sec. 22-37. - Angle parking. 
(a)  The city manager shall determine upon what streets angle parking shall be permitted and shall so mark the parking spaces on such streets, but angle parking shall not be authorized upon any federal aid or state highway within this city unless the state highway commission has determined that the roadway is of sufficient width to permit same without interference with the free movement of traffic. 
(b)  Angle parking shall not be permitted at any place where passing traffic would be thereby caused or required to drive upon the left side of the street. 
(c)  Upon those streets which have been marked for angle parking no person shall park or stand a vehicle other than at the angle to the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by such markings, and within the lines as so marked. 
(Code 1968, § 72.05) 
Sec. 22-38. - Loading or unloading at an angle to the curb. 
    The chief of police may permit the backing of a vehicle to the curb for the purpose of loading or unloading of merchandise or materials. 
(Code 1968, § 72.06) 
Sec. 22-39. - Double parking. 
    No person shall at any time double park a vehicle upon any city street for any purpose. 
(Code 1968, § 72.07) 
Sec. 22-40. - Stopping, standing, prohibited in certain places. 
    No person shall stop or park a vehicle, or permit a vehicle within his control to be parked or left standing, at any of the following places: 
(1)  In front of a public or private driveway; 
(2)  Within ten (10) feet of a fire hydrant; 
(3)  On a sidewalk; 
(4)  Within an intersection; 
(5)  On a crosswalk; 
(6)  In any parkway in any street, or in any parkway dividing two (2) streets; 
(7)  Within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within seventy-five (75) feet of such entrance when proper signs are in place; 
(8)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic; 
(9)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of any street; 
(10)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure; 
(11)  At any place where official signs or markings prohibit stopping, standing or parking. 
(Code 1968, § 72.08) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, KRS 189.450. 
Sec. 22-41. - Obstructing traffic. 
    No person shall park any vehicle upon a street or within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such a position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(Code 1968, § 72.09) 
Sec. 22-42. - Seventy-two hour parking. 
    No person shall park a vehicle on any street right-of-way or other public property for a period longer than seventy-two (72) hours without moving such vehicle. 
(Code 1968, § 72.10) 
Sec. 22-43. - Parking for display purposes. 
    No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principal purpose of displaying such vehicle for sale. 
(Code 1968, § 72.11) 
Sec. 22-44. - Parking adjacent to schools. 
    The city manager is authorized to erect signs indicating "No Parking" upon that side of any street adjacent to any school property where such parking would, in his opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous situation. 
(Code 1968, § 72.12) 
Sec. 22-45. - No parking and limited parking zones. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle at any time upon a street where the curb is painted yellow or where signs have been erected by the city manager designating "No Parking." No person shall park a vehicle at any place upon a street in disobedience to a sign indicating that parking is permitted only during or for a limited time or times. 
(b)  The city manager is hereby authorized, whenever in his judgment it is necessary or proper, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a street, or part thereof, constituting the route, or part of the route, of a parade, and he shall erect temporary traffic signs to that effect. It shall be unlawful to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation of such sign or signs. 
(c)  The city manager shall be authorized to cause the curbs to be marked and to erect signs indicating "No Stopping," "Parking" or "Time Limit Parking" upon any street in the city where he determines such action to be conducive to eliminating hazards and expediting the flow of traffic. 
(d)  No person shall park a vehicle at any time on the city off-street parking lots wherein parking spaces are leased to individuals and firms unless they have leased the parking place from the city. 
(Code 1968, § 72.13; Ord. No. 15-75, § 1, 5-28-75) 
Sec. 22-46. - Stopping or standing in hazardous or congested areas. 
    The city manager is authorized to determine and designate by proper signs places in which the stopping or standing of vehicles would create a hazardous condition or would cause congestion in traffic, and when official signs are so erected, no person shall stop or allow the vehicle driven by him to stand in any such designated place. 
(Code 1968, § 72.15) 
Sec. 22-47. - Stopping for loading or unloading only. 
(a)  Loading zones. The city manager is hereby authorized to determine the location of and establish such loading zones as are necessary for the conduct of business, to omit parking meters from such loading zones and to provide proper signs indicating the time or times during which the zones may be used only for loading and unloading. 
(b)  Standing or parking in loading zones. No person shall park a vehicle in a loading zone except for the sole purpose of loading or unloading merchandise or passengers. The use of loading zones for the loading or unloading of passengers shall not exceed three (3) minutes. The use of loading zones for the loading or unloading of merchandise shall be confined to the handling of heavy or bulky materials, and no vehicle shall remain in a loading zone longer than necessary to load or unload same, nor while the operator thereof is soliciting or engaged otherwise than in the loading or unloading of the vehicle, except that a reasonable time shall be allowed for securing a receipt of delivery. 
(c)  Public carrier stands. The city manager is authorized to establish bus stops, taxicab stands and stands for other passenger common carrier motor vehicles on such public streets in such places and in such number as he shall determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public, and to cause such stands to be designated by appropriate signs. 
(d)  Parking of buses. The driver of a bus shall not park upon any street in the city except at a designated bus stop. 
(e)  Stopping to discharge passengers. It shall be unlawful for the operator of any bus to receive or discharge passengers in a bus stop without first having stopped such bus with its two (2) right wheels within twelve (12) inches of and parallel with the curb. 
(f)  Restricted use of bus and taxicab stands. No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop or a taxicab in a taxicab stand, when such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately marked. 
(Code 1968, § 72.16) 
Sec. 22-48. - Opening doors of parked vehicles. 
    No person shall open the door of any parked vehicle, which door opens on the street side of such vehicle, when any other vehicle or bicycle is approaching within fifty (50) feet to the rear thereof. 
(Code 1968, § 71.18) 
Sec. 22-49. - Parking in city parking lots restricted during certain hours. 
(a)  No person shall park a motor vehicle during the hours between 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., prevailing time, on any city-owned or operated parking lot in any parking space which is leased by the city to another person or designated for city business vehicles only. 
(b)  The chief of police, or his subordinates in the police department, are hereby authorized to have removed any vehicle parked in violation of subsection (a) at the expense of the owner of the vehicle and to have the vehicle kept and impounded until the charges for the removal of same, together with any fine levied are paid. 
(c)  Any person engaged by the police department to move and impound any vehicle in violation of subsection (a), shall exercise reasonable care in so doing and provide such storage facilities as may be necessary, and for such service and storage shall have a lien on the vehicle for the reasonable value of the charges for the towing and storage. 
(Ord. No. 22-68, §§ 1-3, 7-31-68) 
Sec. 22-50. - Parking permit required for Water Street parking lot. 
(a)  That certain lot of ground owned by the city fronting Water Street south of the police station and west of Water Street is hereby designated as a paid public parking lot. 
(b)  Except on Sundays and legal holidays, no person shall park a vehicle in the parking lot unless he has purchased a parking permit from the director of finance. The fee shall be determined from time to time by the board of commissioners and kept on file in the clerk's office. 
(c)  "Legal holidays" as used in this section means New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day, Veterans Day, Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day and no others. 
(d)  The chief of police shall be authorized to cause any vehicle parked in such parking lot in violation of this section to be removed and stored, in which event the owner or bailee of such vehicle shall be entitled to obtain possession thereof upon payment of the costs reasonably incurred in connection with such removal and storage. 
(Ord. No. 21-80, §§ 1-5, 5-27-80) 
Sec. 22-51. - Impounding vehicle. 
(a)  The police department shall have the right to remove or cause to be removed any vehicle from any street or highway that may be abandoned, unlawfully parked or found to constitute a hazard to safety, where the owner or person in charge of such vehicle cannot be found or is unable to act, and, if necessary for such purpose, may use such force as may be necessary to enter such vehicle and cause the same to be placed in condition to be moved, and may engage any reputable person engaged in the business of towing or storing vehicles, for such purposes. 
(b)  A person engaged by the police department to move any vehicle, as provided in this section, shall exercise reasonable and ordinary care in so doing, shall provide such storage facilities therefor as required by law of bailees-for-hire, and for such service and storage shall have a lien on the vehicle for the reasonable value of the charges for such towing, labor and storage. 
(Code 1968, § 72.14) 
Sec. 22-52. - Administrative charge; penalties. 
    Whomever violates any provision of this article shall be required to pay a ten dollar ($10.00) administrative charge to the Department of Finance, Henderson, Kentucky. 
    Any person, business, firm or corporation found to be in violation of Article II, Division 1, shall pay the said ten dollar ($10.00) administrative charge within ten (10) days of the issuance of said violation. Failure to pay the said administrative charge will result in the issuance of the summons to the Henderson District Court for violation of Chapter 22, Article II, Division 1 of the Henderson Code of Ordinances, in compliance with the penalties established by the Kentucky Revised Statutes and the Henderson Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1968, § 73.99; Ord. No. 30-78, § 5, 9-26-78; Ord. No. 16-79, 6-26-79; Ord. No. 20-80, § 14, 5-27-80; Ord. No. 21-80, § 6, 5-27-80; Ord. No. 33-88, 7-26-88) 
Sec. 22-53. - Removal of chalk marks used for enforcement of parking violations prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall remove chalk marks placed by the chief of police or any member of the city police department on vehicle tires in connection with enforcing the traffic and motor vehicles section of the Henderson Code of Ordinances, particularly section 22-66 of the Code of Ordinances of the city. 
(b)  Should the violation occur in the presence of the chief of police, or any member of the city police department, the provisions of section 22-52 of the Code of Ordinances of the city shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 61-87, 11-24-87) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 67-87, adopted Nov. 24, 1987, did not specifically amend the Code; hence inclusion of said provisions herein as § 22-53 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 22-54. - On-street parking of boats, campers, etc. prohibited. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed. 
(1)  Vehicle: A machine propelled by power or other than human power, designed to prevail along the ground, or by water, by use of wheels, treads, runners or slides, and transport persons or property or pull machinery, and shall include without limitation automobile, truck, trailer, motorcycle, tractor, buggy, wagon, 4-wheelers, 3-wheelers, boat, whether or not equipped with a motor, and all vehicles passing over or on the said public streets. 
(2)  Substantially: Means to remove or relocate to private property the said vehicle or trailer from any street or public right-of-way within the City of Henderson. 
(3)  Trailer: Any vehicle designed to be drawn by a motor vehicle. 
(b)  Parking restricted. No person shall stop, stand or park any object, trailer or vehicle, including but not limited to boats, campers, tractor trailers or trailers on any city street for more than any one seventy-two-hour period. 
    The owner or operator of the said vehicle or trailers, shall be required to substantially relocate the trailer or vehicle in order to not be in violation of this ordinance. 
(c)  Penalty: Whoever violates any provision of this section shall be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Failure to remove or relocate the said vehicle or trailer shall subject the vehicle or trailer to removal by the city at the expense and responsibility of the owner of said property. 
(Ord. No. 30-92, 8-25-92) 
Secs. 22-55-22-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARKING[2] 

Footnotes:

Former Div. 2 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1968, §§ 73.01, 73.03-13, 73.98 and Ord. No. 29-71, § 1, 5-11-71; Ord. No. 1-75, 1-14-75; Ord. No. 20-80, §§ 1-13, 5-27-80, and Ord. No. 15-18, 4-14-88. 

Sec. 22-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used herein, shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  Loading zones shall mean a space or section of the street adjacent to the curb set aside for the exclusive use of loading or unloading person, or supplies and merchandise. 
(2)  Park or parking shall mean the standing of a vehicle whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers and merchandise. 
(3)  Vehicle shall mean any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported upon a street or highway, except those operated upon rails or tracks. 
(Ord. No. 9-96, § E, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 22-62. - Limited free parking. 
    There shall be no charge for the parking of vehicles on the public streets or at the Second Street Boat/Watercraft Trailer Parking Area provided, however, that: 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle parked for a period longer than two (2) consecutive hours, unless otherwise designated for a shorter period of time by the city manager or unless the motor vehicle has a valid residential parking permit affixed to its rear window, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. of any day, except Saturday, Sunday and legal holidays, in the marked parking spaces on those sections of public streets in the downtown area as follows: 
 First Street-From Water Street to Green Street; 
 Second Street-From Water Street to Green Street; 
 Third Street-From Water Street to the mid-block alley east of Elm Street on the south side of the street; 
 Third Street-From Main Street to Green Street on the north side of the street; 
 Water Street-From Washington Street to Third Street; 
 Main Street-From Washington Street to a point approximately two hundred fifteen (215) feet north of Third Street on the west side of the street; 
 Main Street-From Washington Street to a point approximately two hundred twenty (220) feet north of Third Street on the east side of the street; 
 Elm Street-From the entrance of the Municipal Center to a point approximately ninety-three (93) feet north of Third Street on the west side of the street; 
 Elm Street-From Center Street to a point approximately seventy (70) feet north of Third Street on the east side of the street; and 
(b)  On Saturdays and Sundays from May 1 to September 30, and on Memorial Day, Independence Day, and Labor Day, no motor vehicle shall be parked or allowed to stand unattended in the Second Street Boat/Watercraft Trailer Parking Area except for boat/watercraft trailers or vehicles with a watercraft roof rack carrier that have affixed a current boat/watercraft trailer parking sticker issued pursuant to division 2, boat/watercraft trailer parking permit of chapter 25, waterways, or motor vehicles parked in spaces designated by signs as "Playground Parking." For all other days, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. of any day (except as designated above), it shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle to be parked for a period longer than two (2) consecutive hours, unless otherwise designated for a shorter period of time by the city manager or designated by signage in the marked parking spaces anywhere within the Second Street Boat/Watercraft Trailer Parking Area, except for motor vehicles towing boat/watercraft trailers or vehicles with a watercraft roof rack carrier that have affixed a current boat/watercraft parking sticker issued pursuant to division 2, boat/watercraft trailer parking permit of chapter 25, waterways, of this Code. 
(c)  The "Second Street Boat/Watercraft Trailer Parking Area" as used herein is that paved area extending west from Water Street on a line with Second Street, then north on the connector road running along the Ohio River, and then east on a line with Third Street to Water Street. "Legal holidays" as used herein means New Year's Day, Martin Luther King Day, Good Friday, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, day after Thanksgiving, Christmas Day, and the day before or the day after Christmas Day, as designated by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 9-96, § A, 2-27-96; Ord. No. 12-2001, 6-12-01; Ord. No. 10-14, 3-25-14; Ord. No. 05-19, Exh. A, 2-26-19) 
Sec. 22-63. - Evading time limitations prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to move a vehicle from one (1) space to another for the purpose of evading time limitations on parking. Therefore, if a vehicle is shown by the electronic marking device used by the city's parking enforcement officer to have occupied parking spaces within the state regulated areas more than ten (10) times in a one-week period (Monday through Friday), then the owner or operator of said vehicle shall be deemed to have moved said vehicle for the purpose of evading time limitations on parking which shall constitute a parking violation and such violator shall be notified in writing of such violation and shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 22-64 below. 
(Ord. No. 9-96, § B, 2-27-96; Ord. No. 67-17, 12-12-17) 
Sec. 22-64. - Fines. 
(a)  An owner(s) of a motor vehicle which has violated the provisions of sections 22-62 or 22-63 regarding parking may, within five (5) business days after the time when notice of the violation was attached to such vehicle, or received by mail or hand delivered, pay the director of finance, or his/her duly authorized representative, in full satisfaction of such violation, the sum of five dollars ($5.00) if such violation is for overtime parking on public streets, or at the Second Street Boat/Watercraft Trailer Parking Area, and twenty dollars ($20.00) if such violation is for parking in excess of ten (10) times in a one-week period (Monday through Friday). 
(b)  If the owner(s) fails to pay for such violation within the five (5) business day period, he/she may within ten (10) business days after the time when such notice was attached to such vehicle, received by mail or hand delivered, pay the director of finance, or his/her duly authorized representative, in full satisfaction of such violation, the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) if such violation is for overtime parking on public streets, ten dollars ($10.00) if such violation is for overtime parking at the Second Street Boat/Watercraft Trailer Parking Area and thirty dollars ($30.00) if such violation is for parking in excess of ten (10) times in a one-week period (Monday through Friday). Fines for any violations of this section may be waived by the city manager, or his designee, upon determination by the city manager, or his designee, that mitigating circumstances exist justifying such waiver. The burden of showing mitigating circumstances lies solely upon the violator and must be presented to the city manager, or his designee, prior to the matter being referred to court for nonpayment. 
(Ord. No. 9-96, § C, 2-27-96; Ord. No. 12-2001, 6-12-01; Ord. No. 10-14, 3-25-14; Ord. No. 67-17, 12-12-17; Ord. No. 05-19, Exh. A, 2-26-19) 
Sec. 22-65. - Parking spaces designated loading zone. 
(a)  The city manager shall designate certain parking spaces as loading zones. Such spaces shall be used only for ingress and egress and for the loading and unloading of property or merchandise delivered to or from premises adjacent to or in proximity thereto, and such spaces shall be marked off adjacent or in proximity thereto. Such spaces shall be marked off only when the property to be served has no other reasonable entry or outlet, and when the nature of the property, or merchandise to be delivered is such as would be impracticable to handle otherwise. 
(b)  No person, firm or corporation shall park a vehicle in a loading zone except for the purpose of and during the actual time of loading or unloading merchandise or passengers. Whenever possible, trucks loading or unloading shall park in the center of the street astride the center line, except trucks delivering merchandise that required parking into the curb, in which event this will be permitted in a regular parking space or spaces, and there will be no violation of this provisions during the time the truck is actually being loaded or unloaded. 
(Ord. No. 9-96, § D, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 22-66. - Residential parking permit. 
(a)  Resident(s) of apartments located within the area designated in subsection 22-62(a), which do not have any off-street parking as part of the residence, may submit an application for a residential parking permit to allow them to exceed the two (2) consecutive hours limit as designated in subsection 22-62(a). The permit owner will still have to abide by all other parking regulations, including but not limited to section 22-42 and complying with city official's orders to move vehicles for special events, street or sidewalk repair work and/or paving, or street cleaning. 
(b)  Only one (1) permit per eligible residential unit will be issued. 
(c)  The application for a residential parking permit shall provide the resident's name, the owner of the motor vehicle to be permitted; the residential address; the operator's state driver's license number; the motor vehicle make, model, color, and license number; and other information requested on the application form. The applicant shall provide proof of residency and any other necessary information as required by the city finance department. 
(d)  Residential parking permits shall be issued on a quarterly basis or an annual basis. The permit will expire at the end of the quarter, or for annual permits on December 31 or when the resident no longer resides at the apartment designated in the application. The quarterly permit fee is forty-five dollars ($45.00) and the annual permit fee is one hundred eighty dollars ($180.00). The fee for quarterly permits issued after the beginning of a quarter will be prorated on a monthly basis. The fee for annual permits issued after January 31 will be prorated on a monthly basis. 
(e)  The permit is nontransferable except on the following basis: 
(1)  If the resident changes vehicles; or 
(2)  If the resident moves to another eligible residential apartment within the area designated in subsection 22-62(a) and the apartment still has an available parking permit for the apartment; or 
(3)  The permit can be transferred to another resident in the apartment unit. 
(f)  At any time, annual permit can be refunded on a prorated monthly basis upon return of the residential parking permit to the city finance department. 
(g)  The residential parking permit shall be a decal and shall be affixed only to the motor vehicle for which it was issued. The decal shall be permanently attached to the inside lower corner of the rear window, driver's side and must be clearly visible from outside the vehicle. Information shown on the permit decal shall include but not be limited to the permit number and the expiration date. 
(h)  If it is found that the residential parking permit is being used by someone other than a resident of the apartment to which the permit is issued, then the residential parking permit will be revoked and no parking permit for the resident shall be issued for a period of twelve (12) months. A resident may appeal this revocation to the city commission. 
(i)  Residents with expired permits must remove the expired permits from their vehicle window within five (5) days of the expiration of the permit. 
(g)  The residential parking permit shall be a decal and shall be affixed only to the motor vehicle for which it was issued. The decal shall be permanently attached to the inside lower corner of the rear window, driver's side and must be clearly visible from outside the vehicle. Information shown on the permit decal shall include but not be limited to the permit number and the expiration date. 
(h)  If it is found that the residential parking permit is being used by someone other than a resident of the apartment to which the permit is issued, then the residential parking permit will be revoked and no parking permit for the resident shall be issued for a period of twelve (12) months. A resident may appeal this revocation to the city commission. 
(i)  Residents with expired permits must remove the expired permits from their vehicle window within five (5) days of the expiration of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 13-14, 4-8-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-14, adopted March 25, 2014, repealed former § 22-66, which pertained to parking advisory committee established; purpose; meetings; terms, and derived from Ord. No. 12-96, adopted March 12, 1996. 
 Subsequently, Ord. No. 13-14, adopted April 8, 2014, enacted new provisions as herein set out. 
Secs. 22-67-22-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SNOW ROUTES 

Sec. 22-81. - Streets designated. 
    The following portions of the following streets are hereby declared to be snow route streets: 
Adams Street 41 North to 5th Street Atkinson Street McKinley Avenue to Gregory Drive Barker Road Elm Street to Sunset Lane Clay Street Green Street to U.S. 41 Elm Street First Street to Barker Road Drury Lane Green Street to South Main Street First Street Main Street to Elm Street Heilman Avenue 5th Street to McKinley Avenue Kimsey Lane Adams Street to Redbanks McKinley Avenue Heilman Avenue to Atkinson Street Sand Lane South Main Street to Highway 136 South Main Street Drury Lane to First Street Sunset Lane Barker Road to Watson Lane Watson Lane Sunset Lane to U.S. 60 East 5th Street Elm Street to Heilman Avenue 12th Street Adams Street to hospital 14th Street Elm Street to Green Street  
(Ord. No. 30-78, § 2, 9-26-78) 
Sec. 22-82. - Parking prohibited during snow emergency. 
    Upon a declaration by the mayor, after recommendation by the city manager that a snow emergency exists caused by heavy snowfall in the city, no parking shall be permitted upon the routes listed in section 22-81 by any vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 30-78, § 2, 9-26-78) 
Sec. 22-83. - Posting. 
    The routes in section 22-81 are hereby designated as snow routes and reasonable insignias shall be placed on, the routes to indicate to the public that such streets are snow routes. 
(Ord. No. 30-78, § 3, 9-26-78) 
Sec. 22-84. - Removal of vehicles. 
    After declaration of a snow emergency by the mayor, no parking shall be permitted upon a snow route, and any vehicle found parked upon the snow route may be towed and removed by the city at the cost of the owner or possessor of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 30-78, § 4, 9-26-78) 
Secs. 22-85-22-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TRUCKS 

Sec. 22-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Gross weight means the weight of any truck and the heaviest load that the vehicle may be used to carry at any time on the highways and streets within the corporate limits of the city. The term "gross weight" shall not mean actual weight but shall mean the weight of the vehicle and its load carrying capacity. 
    Truck means any motor propelled vehicle used for the transportation of property on a public highway or street, whether operated as a unit or in combination with other vehicles such as trailers. 
(Code 1968, § 74.01) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-102. - Classification of streets. 
    The streets and highways located within the corporate limits of the city are hereby classified as to the maximum limits of gross weight of trucks which shall be permitted to use such streets and highways as follows: 
Highways and Streets Classification Gross Weight Limit State and federal highways AAA Such weight limits as are set by the laws of the state and the regulations established thereunder Streets requiring the use of heavy-duty trucks AAA 80,000 pounds Streets requiring the use of medium-duty trucks A 44,000 pounds All other streets B 10,000 pounds Beginning at the intersection of Washington and Letcher Streets, running thence in a westerly direction on Washington to the intersection of Washington and Meadow Streets; thence northerly on Meadow to the intersection of Meadow and Center Streets; thence easterly on Center Street to the end AAA 80,000 pounds Beginning at the intersection of South Green and Vine Streets; thence in an easterly direction on Vine to the intersection of Vine and South Alves Streets AAA 80,000 pounds Racetrack Road from Stratman Road to U.S. Highway 41 North AAA 80,000 pounds  
(Code 1968, § 74.02; Ord. No. 7-79, § I, 5-8-79; Ord. No. 25-82, 7-27-82) 
State Law reference- Maximum weight permitted on highway, KRS 189.210 et seq. 
Sec. 22-103. - Official city routing map. 
    The official city map relating to the use of the streets and highways located within the corporate limits of the city by trucks and the classification and designation of such streets and highways as to gross weight limits is hereby adopted and approved by reference as if incorporated herein. 
(Code 1968, § 74.03; Ord. No. 7-79, § II, 5-8-79) 
Sec. 22-104. - Designation of truck routes. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized to designate truck routes within the city. 
(Ord. No. 7-79, § II, 5-8-79; Ord. No. 37-97, 10-28-97) 
Sec. 22-105. - Unlawful operation of trucks. 
    No person shall operate a truck upon any street or highway located within the corporate limits of the city where the gross weight of the truck is in excess of the gross weight limit prescribed for the street by this article and the approved official city routing map. 
(Code 1968, § 74.04) 
Sec. 22-106. - Exemptions for trucks used for certain purposes. 
    The provisions of section 22-105 shall not apply to: 
(1)  Trucks used in pick-up or delivery service to and from residences within the city when actually in use for this purpose; 
(2)  Trucks used for the pick-up and delivery of commercial merchandise, material, supplies and other property to business establishments not located on an established route as designated in this article or the official city routing map when actually in use for this purpose; 
(3)  Persons who possess a special permit secured from the city manager. This permit shall not be granted except in unusual or extraordinary cases and shall not be inconsistent with the terms and spirit of this article. If the city manager approves such permit, he may attach such necessary conditions and requirements as he deems reasonable and necessary for the proper and efficient routing of trucks upon the streets of the city. 
(Code 1968, § 74.05; Ord. No. 7-79, § V, 5-8-79) 
Sec. 22-107. - Regulations and enforcement. 
    The city engineer shall make such regulations and erect such traffic signs as he deems reasonable and necessary and not inconsistent with this article for the safe and efficient routing of trucks within the city. The chief of police, or his subordinates, shall have the power to enforce the provisions of this article and any regulations established thereunder. 
(Code 1968, § 74.06) 
Sec. 22-108. - License required for operation of trucks over designated weight. 
(a)  No person shall operate on any street or highway within the city any motor truck or semi-trailer truck whose gross weight, including load, exceeds eighteen thousand (18,000) pounds without first procuring from the city a license for the operation thereof, which license shall extend to the owner of such truck the privilege of operation within a radius of fifteen (15) miles of the city subject to the limitations prescribed by KRS 186.270. 
(b)  The fee for each motor truck or semi-trailer licensed pursuant to subsection (a) shall be thirty-five dollars ($35.00) which shall be collected by the city clerk, and for which the city clerk shall issue a license plate or sticker. The license plate or sticker shall be prominently displayed upon the truck or semi-trailer truck for which it is issued, so as to be plainly visible from the outside of the vehicle. 
(c)  Each motor truck or semi-trailer truck licensed pursuant to this section shall be exempt from any other license required by ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1968, §§ 74.07-74.09) 
Sec. 22-109. - Traction engines and heavy vehicles. 
    No person shall pull, drive, run or propel any traction engine, crusher, truck or like vehicle that has corrugated metal tires or tires with lugs or spikes upon or over any streets of the city except between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m., and any person desiring to move such engine or vehicle upon such streets shall obtain from the chief of police permission to do so, in which event the chief of police shall prescribe the route to be followed in moving such engine or vehicle and the time therefor. No such engine or vehicle shall be moved on any of the streets of this city except in accordance with such permission. 
(Code 1968, § 74.10) 
Sec. 22-110. - Projecting loads. 
    When any part of a load projects more than five (5) feet beyond a vehicle a red flag by day and a red light by night must be placed upon the outward extremity of such projection. 
(Code 1968, § 74.11) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, KRS 189.060(3). 
Sec. 22-111. - Sifting or leaking loads. 
    No person shall operate any vehicle unless such vehicle is so constructed and laden as to prevent its content from dropping, sifting or otherwise escaping therefrom onto the roadway. 
(Code 1968, § 74.12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, KRS 189.150. 
Sec. 22-112. - Transportation of explosives. 
    No person shall transport any explosives in quantities of more than fifty (50) pounds into or through the city without a separate written permit from the chief of police, and no person shall transport any explosives in quantities of more than fifty (50) pounds through the city except in a vehicle with springs and with a top and with a sign "Explosives-Danger" painted on each of its four (4) sides or carried upon a vertical pole at the front of such vehicle high enough and large enough to be readable from both front and rear for a distance of one hundred (100) feet; provided further, that if the transportation be at night, such sign shall be luminous so as to be readable from both front and rear for a distance of one hundred (100) feet. 
(Code 1968, § 74.13) 
State Law reference- Vehicles transporting explosives to be marked, KRS 189.160. 
Sec. 22-113. - Parking generally. 
(a)  Trucks of one ton and more capacity. All trucks of one ton capacity and over shall be parked in the center of the street on the following designated streets in the business district: 
(1)  First Street from Water to Green Streets; 
(2)  Second Street from Water to Green Streets; 
(3)  Main Street from First to Third Streets; 
(4)  Elm Street from First to Second Streets. 
On all other streets in the business district, curb parking shall be used. If it is necessary for trucks of one ton capacity and over to park at the curb of any of the above-designated streets, the operator of such truck shall contact the police department and secure the attendance of a policeman while so parked. The time limit for parking of trucks as provided in this subsection shall be thirty (30) minutes, and any truck or trucks that park in excess of this limit shall be subject to the penalty set forth in this section. This subsection shall apply to all vehicles engaged in the delivery of United States mail. 
(b)  Trucks of less than one ton capacity. For all trucks under one ton capacity, curb parking on all streets in the city is hereby required. 
(c)  Time section is effective, etc. The regulations set forth in this section shall apply during the hours from 7:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., inclusive, on week days from Monday to Saturday, inclusive. No other middle of the street parking is permitted. Any restriction of parking hours deemed in the public interest may be set by the city manager and the chief of police. 
(d)  Procedure on violation of section. The chief of police and his authorized assistants, under the city manager, shall keep account of all violations of this section. The police chief or his authorized assistants shall keep account of and report the location of vehicles parked in violation of any of the provisions of this section, the date and hour of such violation, the make and the state license number of such vehicle, or any other facts and knowledge which is necessary to a thorough understanding of the circumstances attending such violation. The police chief or his authorized assistants shall attach to such vehicle a notice stating that it has been parked in violation of this section and instructing the owner or operator to report to the police headquarters in regard to such violation. The owner or operator may, within twenty-four (24) hours after the time when such notice is attached to such vehicle, pay the chief of police or one of his duly authorized assistants, in full satisfaction of such violation, the sum of three dollars ($3.00). In such case, the name of the owner or operator shall not be added to the records of traffic violators. Upon failure of any person to answer charges for violation of the parking requirements as herein provided for, the parking complaint shall be treated in the same manner now applied to other traffic violations, in that a warrant may be issued for his arrest. 
(e)  Obstruction of traffic. Except as otherwise provided for herein, trucks shall not be parked in any location or in any manner so as to obstruct the normal traffic flow or to create potential traffic hazards. 
(Code 1968, § 74.14; Ord. No. 4-74, § 2, 1-22-74; Ord. No. 7-79, § IV, 5-8-79) 
Sec. 22-114. - Transportation of coal. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of this article, no person shall transport coal over the streets of the city without first obtaining a special permit from the city manager. If the city manager approves such permit, he may attach such conditions and requirements as he deems reasonable and necessary. 
(Ord. No. 7-79, § III, 5-8-79) 
Sec. 22-115. - Penalty for violations. 
    Whoever violates the provisions of this article or any regulation established thereunder shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Code 1968, § 74.99) 
Secs. 22-116-22-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TRAINS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Railroads-Organization and operating regulations, KRS Ch. 277. 

Sec. 22-131. - Speed generally. 
(a)  North bound railroad locomotives or railroad trains or railroad cars shall not exceed the speed limit authorized by the appropriate railroad authorities, from the south boundary of the city limits until the engine of such trains crosses Clay Street. From said Clay Street crossing to the point where the engine crosses the north boundary of the city, such trains shall not travel at a speed in excess of twenty-five (25) miles an hour.
