DIVISION 3. - WATER AND SEWER COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Waterworks, KRS 96.320 et seq. 

Sec. 23-36. - Established. 
    The management, control and operation of the water and sewer systems of the city shall be carried on by a commission to be known as the "Water and Sewer Commission of the City of Henderson" created, appointed and functioning, as provided in this division. The water, wastewater and stormwater systems of the city shall conduct daily business as the "Henderson Water Utility," abbreviated when appropriate as "HWU." 
(Ord. No. 06-11, 3-22-11; Ord. No. 27-18, 9-11-18) 
Sec. 23-37. - Composition. 
    The water and sewer commission shall consist of five (5) persons who shall be qualified voters of outstanding reputation for ability and integrity in the city who are not related within the fourth degree of consanguinity with the mayor or any other member of the board of commissioners of the city at the time of their appointment and who shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent and approval of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 23-38. - Terms; vacancies. 
(a)  The water and sewer commission first appointed after January 1, 1954, shall meet and select by lot their terms of office, one (1) of which shall be for three (3) years, two (2) of which shall be for two (2) years, and two (2) of which shall be for one (1) year, from January 1, 1954. 
(b)  In the event of a vacancy and also prior to or upon the expiration of the term of office of any appointed commissioner a successor shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent and approval of the board of commissioners. Any commissioner may resign and shall be deemed to have automatically resigned upon becoming a candidate for any public office. All vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term and all other appointments shall be for a term of three (3) years, and all appointments shall continue until the successors shall have qualified. 
(c)  Any commissioner shall be eligible for reappointment upon the expiration of his term. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 23-39. - Rules and regulations; quorum. 
    The water and sewer commission may adopt rules and bylaws for the time and place of its meetings and the conduct thereof and three (3) commissioners shall constitute a quorum at any meeting. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 23-40. - Removal of members. 
(a)  Any water and sewer commissioner failing to attend four (4) successive meetings without cause acceptable and approved by the commission may be thereby automatically removed from office by declaration of the commission and the vacancy shall be filled as hereinbefore provided. 
(b)  Each commissioner shall be removable for cause by the recorded majority vote of the board of commissioners of the city after hearing. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 23-41. - Officers; custodian of funds; depository. 
    The water and sewer commission shall annually designate one (1) of its members chairman and another as secretary. Insofar as permissible by law it shall appoint a treasurer who shall be custodian of all funds collected or to be expended by or under order of the commission, and the commission shall designate a bank which is a member of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation as depository for all funds held by the commission, but if and to whatever extent any of the provisions for the appointment of a separate treasurer or for the designation of a depository shall be adjudicated by a court of competent jurisdiction to be unauthorized then the general laws of the state with respect to the custody and deposit of municipal funds shall be applicable. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 23-42. - Authority; supervision; management; control. 
(a)  The water and sewer commission shall have full and complete authority, supervision, management, and control of the combined and consolidated municipal water works and sewer system, stormwater management, control and abatement, including, but not limited to, all rate and service policies, design, plan review, construction, maintenance, monitoring as well as the collection, deposit and expenditure of all funds constituting, directly or indirectly, income or revenues of the combined and consolidated works and systems and also the maintenance, operation and extension of the works and systems. 
(b)  All charges for the use and services rendered by the works and systems shall be collected and accounted for by the water and sewer commission in the manner and form required by law and the ordinances of the city and all disbursements for the account of the works and systems shall be ordered paid out only upon approval of the commission; provided, however, all such supervision, management and control of the works and systems, including the collection, depositing and accounting for the income and revenues therefrom and disbursements for the account of the works and systems shall be consistent and in accordance with the ordinance or ordinances pursuant to which the city may have authorized and issued any bonds from time to time outstanding which by their terms are payable from and secured by the income and revenues of the works and systems or any portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 23-43. - Employment of general manager and management employees. 
    The water and sewer commission shall have power to employ, fix the compensation of, and discharge, the general manager, the chief financial officer, the project engineer, and the director of operations. The general manager shall direct, employ, fix the compensation of, and discharge all other employees of the works and systems. All employees of the works and systems, other than the positions of general manager, chief financial officer, the project engineer, and the director of operations, shall be subject to and under the protection of the civil service system of the City of Henderson. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, 3-22-11; Ord. No. 19-16, 6-14-16; Ord. No. 56-17, 9-26-17; Ord. No. 27-18, 9-11-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 56-17, adopted Sept. 26, 2017, changed the title of § 23-43 from "Employment of general manager, director of engineering and employees" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 23-44. - Protection of bond holders. 
(a)  The board of commissioners enacts sections of this division for the assurance and protection of the holder or holders of bonds of the city payable from the income and revenues of the works and systems for an efficient operation and maintenance thereof. 
(b)  No amendment or repeal of such sections shall be enacted unless at least thirty (30) days prior to the introduction thereof at a meeting of the board of commissioners the proposed ordinance, amendment or repeal shall have been mailed to all known holders of any outstanding bonds and shall have theretofore been published in a newspaper having general circulation in the city at least once each week for four (4) consecutive weeks. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 23-45. - Position of general manager established; appointment; compensation; responsibilities. 
(a)  The position of General Manager of the Henderson Water Utility shall not be subject to or under the civil service systems of the city. 
(b)  The general manager shall be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the water and sewer commission. 
(c)  The compensation of the general manager of the water and sewer department shall be fixed by the water and sewer commission. 
(d)  The general manager shall, subject to full and complete supervision and control of the water and sewer commission, have the general responsibility for the overall operation of the Henderson Water Utility including, without limitation, the financial and personnel management of the department, the operation of the combined waterworks and sewage system of the city and such other duties and responsibilities as the water and sewer commission may from time to time authorize and direct. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 23-45.1. - General powers of the water and sewer commission. 
(a)  In addition to such other powers that may be delegated to it from time to time by the board of commissioners, the water and sewer commission shall have full and complete jurisdiction, control, possession, management, and supervision of all public water, wastewater, combined wastewater, and stormwater works and facilities within the city service area, including, but not limited to, the maintenance, operation, reconstruction, improvement, additions, and extensions thereto; and, generally, in the name, and for and on behalf of the city, all of the authority, powers, privileges and jurisdiction necessary or proper to carry out such general powers. 
(b)  The water and sewer commission shall, from time to time, recommend to the board of commissioners the establishment, levy and collection of such rates, fees, charges, and surcharges deemed by it to be necessary and appropriate to meet the projected revenue requirements necessary to maintain and operate the complete water, wastewater, combined wastewater and stormwater collection, treatment and abatement systems in such manner as complies with federal and state laws and regulations. 
(c)  The water and sewer commission shall have full right and authority to cause its employees and agents to enter upon any lands, waters and/or premises for the purpose of making surveys, monitoring, inspections and examinations or for any other purpose deemed necessary or appropriate to carry out the general purposes of the water and sewer commission. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to be a delegation of power by the board of commissioners of the city to the water and sewer commission beyond that which is permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 23-45.2. - Procurement powers of the water and sewer commission. 
(a)  Pursuant to KRS 45A.360, the provisions of KRS 45A.345 to 45A.460 shall govern all procurement activities of the water and sewer commission and the Henderson Water Utility (HWU). 
(b)  The general manager shall be responsible for administration of the procurement functions of HWU, and may delegate to department heads and employees such authority as may be appropriate and necessary to perform these functions. The general manager, with the advice and consent of the water and sewer commission, shall establish written policies and procedures as necessary to carry out purchasing, payment, bidding and contracting. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall relieve HWU of the responsibility to comply with any procurement requirements imposed by an agency from which HWU may receive grant or loan funds, including but not limited to state and federal agencies. 
(Ord. No. 56-17, 9-26-17) 
Secs. 23-45.3-23-45.10. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - WATER SUPPLY SHORTAGE RESPONSE 

Sec. 23-45.11. - Declaration of water supply shortage; rationing. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to provide for the declaration of phases of water supply shortages and for the implementation of voluntary and mandatory water conservation measures affecting the water customers of the city in the event a shortage is declared. 
(b)  Definitions. As used in this section, the following words and terms shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  Customer . Any person using water for any purpose from the city's water distribution system. 
(2)  HWU . The Henderson Water Utility. 
(3)  Outside water use . Nonessential uses of water outside of buildings, including, but not limited to: filling and operation of private swimming pools, water features, fountains and reflecting pools; noncommercial washing of motor vehicles, boats and trailers; and watering of lawns, gardens, playing fields and recreational areas, whether public or private. 
(4)  Rationing . Procedures established to provide for the fair distribution of critically limited water supplies, in order to balance demand and supply, and to assure that sufficient water is available to preserve public health and safety. 
(c)  Water shortage phases . In order of increasing severity the following four (4) phases of water shortage are hereby established: 
(1)  Phase 1, advisory. When HWU finds that a potential shortage of potable water exists or will exist, HWU shall publicly declare a water shortage advisory, calling upon all customers of HWU to employ voluntary water conservation and to reduce the use of potable water. 
(2)  Phase 2, alert. When HWU finds that a condition exists where it will not be able to meet the expected needs of its customers for water without a minimal level of water conservation, HWU shall publicly declare a water shortage alert, calling upon all customers to employ voluntary water conservation, and also to restrict outside water use to the following schedule: 
i.  Outside water use for addresses ending in an odd number shall be limited to Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays; and 
ii.  Outside water use for addresses ending in an even number shall be limited to Wednesdays, Fridays and Sundays. 
(3)  Phase 3, emergency. When HWU finds that it is unable to meet the expected needs of its customers, HWU shall publicly declare a water shortage emergency, calling upon customers to comply with mandatory water conservation to eliminate the waste of potable water. All outside water use shall be halted, and water shall be used only as necessary to sustain human life and the lives of domestic pets, to maintain minimum standards of hygiene and sanitation, to provide patient care and rehabilitation in health care facilities, for firefighting, and for essential health and public protection purposes. 
(4)  Phase 4, rationing. When HWU finds that potable water is in critically short supply, and that the conditions specified in subsection (d) below are determined to exist, HWU shall publicly declare water rationing. In the rationing phase, it is imperative that water customers achieve an immediate further reduction in water use in order to extend existing water supplies and, at the same time, assure that sufficient water is available to preserve the public health and sanitation and to provide fire protection service. The mandatory water conservation measures of the emergency phase shall apply, and in addition, HWU may institute temporary service interruptions to all or portions of the water supply system. 
(5)  Length of continuance of declaration. The declaration of a water shortage phase shall continue until HWU finds and publicly declares that the conditions calling for the declaration no longer exist. 
(d)  Basis for rationing. Whenever HWU finds it necessary to allocate critically limited potable water supplies in order to balance water demand and supply, and to assure that sufficient water is available to preserve public health and safety, it shall be empowered to declare the adoption of mandatory rationing, when any of the following conditions is determined to exist: 
(1)  Mandated reductions in systemwide usage have not been achieved; or 
(2)  Mandated reductions in systemwide water usage have been achieved, but have failed to sufficiently extend limited water supplies; or 
(3)  Temporary service interruptions are necessary in order to further extend limited water supplies. 
(e)  Notification. When it is determined that rationing through temporary service interruptions is necessary, HWU shall notify its customers through the public media (newspapers, radio, and television), at least one (1) day prior to the temporary service interruptions that a planned, temporary service interruption is to be imposed. Such notice shall: 
(1)  State the day or days when the temporary service interruptions will occur, including the times when such temporary service interruptions will commence and cease; 
(2)  State whether the temporary service interruptions are to be imposed on the entire system or part thereof, and, if only parts of the system will experience temporary service interruptions, identify geographic boundaries within which such interruptions will occur; and, 
(3)  Advise all customers within the areas affected by temporary service interruptions how to treat any water received from the system for human consumption, during the period of such interruptions and for such additional time as may be necessary until full pressure and water quality is restored in the system. 
(f)  Rationing for hospital facilities. If a temporary service interruption is imposed as authorized by this section, it must provide for the continued delivery of water to hospital facilities within the area affected by such interruption by means of any adequate, alternative delivery measures that may be necessary. 
(g)  Regulations. During the effective period of any water supply shortage, the HWU general manager is empowered to issue such regulations as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this section. Such regulations shall be subject to the approval of the city water and sewer commission at its next meeting. 
(h)  Violations. Any person who violates the provisions of paragraph (c)(2) of this section shall be subject to a fine not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). Any person who violates the provisions of paragraph (c)(3) of this section shall be subject to a fine not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and disconnection of water service. A fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be paid for reconnection of any water service disconnected pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 20-11, 9-27-11) 
Secs. 23-45.12-23-45.15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GAS SERVICE 

Sec. 23-46. - Service lines defined. 
    The general term "service pipe" or "service line" is commonly used to designate the complete line or connection between the city's gas mains. 
(Code 1968, § 52.02) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 23-47. - Requirements and specifications. 
(a)  The requirements and specifications hereinafter set forth in this article governing the installation and maintenance of gas service lines, house piping, appliance connections, meters and regulators on customer's premises, and the inspection and testing of the same are published by the gas department, for the instruction and guidance of those persons doing gas fitting work. These requirements and specifications have been adopted in the interest of safe and adequate service to the customer. 
(b)  These requirements and specifications govern service to both newly constructed buildings and to existing structures where any alterations or changes are being made. It shall be the duty of the customer, owner or his representative to notify the gas department of any changes or alterations, remodeling or reconstruction, or damages to premises affecting gas piping, including meters, regulators, the customer's service line and accident or design, and gas service shall not be resumed to the premises until all requirements have been met and the lines have been inspected, tested and approved. When altering or extending house piping or service lines, all changes shall be made to conform to these requirements and specifications. 
(c)  It is not intended that these requirements and specifications be all inclusive and where unusual conditions arise or where special service is required, the gas department is to be consulted before proceeding with the work. 
(d)  The gas department may refuse gas service to any premises where the gas piping does not conform to these requirements and specifications. The gas department will not assume responsibility for any imperfect material or defective or faulty workmanship in the installation of the customer's house piping, appliances or appliance connections, or for any loss or damage arising from such imperfect material or tested by its representative. 
(Code 1968, § 52.01) 
Sec. 23-48. - Ownership and responsibility. 
(a)  The natural gas service line is the property of Henderson Municipal Gas (City of Henderson/HMG). HMG has jurisdiction from the tap on the main to the meter set location (typically at the residence) and reserves the right to remove facilities not in use for periods in excess of six (6) months. 
(b)  The materials, installation and location of the customer service line shall be subject to requirements and specifications contained herein. Such line shall be subject to the inspection and test at any time as provided. 
(Code 1968, § 52.03; Ord. No. 02-12, § 2, 1-24-12) 
Sec. 23-49. - Materials. 
    Materials used will be in accordance with 49 CFR192-subpart "B". Pipe joining will be in compliance with 49 CFR 192 Subpart "E" Welding of Steel in Pipelines or Subpart "F," Joining of materials other than by welding and be performed by HMG personnel for mains and services. 
(Code 1968, § 52.04; Ord. No. 02-12, § 2, 1-24-12) 
Sec. 23-50. - Installation. 
(a)  As soon as possible, the customer, owner, or his representative, shall contact the gas department for information as to size, location, cost and termination points of the service. At the time of gas service request, the account owner shall provide a contact number, which may be a cell phone or home phone or some other acceptable method of contact for safety and public awareness purposes. 
(b)  The customer service line shall be laid on undisturbed or well compacted soil in a separate trench, avoiding sewers, water pipes, and conduits, and shall not run through septic tanks or leaching beds. It shall not be laid on a bench or offset of a deeper and continuous foundation for the pipe and should be deep enough to provide at least twenty (20) inches of cover over service pipe. 
(c)  The customer service line shall not be laid under concrete or other hard surface walks or driveways except where it may be necessary to cross under such walks or driveways and except where such walks or driveways extend from curb to foundation wall and the full width of the property such as service stations and places of business. 
(d)  No heavy weight or heavy material such as large stones or concrete blocks, and also no cinders or slag shall be placed on the customer's service line or in the fill over the service line. 
(e)  Residential natural gas service installations shall be free for the first one hundred (100) feet to the extent installation is typical in the opinion of the gas director. Beyond one hundred (100) feet an estimate will be provided to owner and HMG shall be reimbursed costs up to limit of estimate. A standard house meter and regulator shall be supplied at no cost. 
(f)  Commercial natural gas service shall be installed for free for the first one hundred (100) feet of service to the extent the installation shall be typical. For any length exceeding one hundred (100) feet an estimate will be provided to owner and HMG shall be reimbursed at cost up to limit of the estimate. Rates and fees shall be as on record with Henderson Municipal Gas. A standard meter (250/425) and regulator (standard pressure) shall be provided free of charge. Any larger volume meters, higher costs meters, and/or regulator required for service will be included in estimate minus the cost of a typical meter set installation. 
(g)  HMG may extend up to two hundred (200) feet of main at no cost for expanded natural gas use at the discretion of the gas director. Anticipated additional service(s), size of pipe (diameter), and type of material will all be factors in consideration of an extension. Costs in excess of the two hundred (200) feet (if allowed for free) with be borne by the person(s) requesting natural gas service to unserved locations. 
(Code 1968, § 52.05; Ord. No. 02-12, § 2, 1-24-12) 
Sec. 23-51. - General requirements governing service lines. 
    Each building served with gas shall have a separate customer service lines, except for doubles, duplexes, apartments, terraces or flats, one customer service line only is required and meters shall be manifolded at one (1) location, where the gas main is located in the alley, the curb cock and box shall be located adjacent to the rear property line. Where the gas main is located on the roadway or between the curb and property line, the curb cock and box shall be located adjacent to the front property line. 
(Code 1968, § 52.06) 
Sec. 23-52. - Meters and service pressure regulators in general. 
(a)  The gas department will furnish and connect a meter for each customer, and this meter shall remain the property of the gas department. 
(b)  Where service is provided from intermediate or high pressure lines the gas department will furnish the necessary pressure regulator, and this pressure regulator shall remain the property of the gas department. 
(c)  A suitable vent, terminating in an insect and rain proof fitting, shall be provided for all service pressure regulators. 
(d)  Service pressure regulators when incorporating a relief device and installed inside shall be vented to the outside to a safe location using three-fourths-inch pipe. 
(e)  Service pressure regulators that do not incorporate a relief device and are installed inside shall be vented to the outside to a safe location using one-fourth-inch pipe or three-eighths-inch metal tubing. 
(f)  Only HMG personnel shall be allowed to remove or replace gas meters and related equipment such as regulators. HMG maintains jurisdiction to the outlet of the meter. The owner of property shall have house piping installed in accordance with current requirements as outlined in other sections. 
(Code 1968, § 52.07; Ord. No. 02-12, § 2, 1-24-12) 
Sec. 23-53. - Location of meters and right of entry to meters. 
(a)  The gas department reserves the right to determine meter locations. 
(b)  Gas meters should be installed as near as practicable to the point where the service enters the building. Gas, electric and water meters shall be so located as to be readily accessible for examination, reading and replacement. 
(c)  All piping from the point where the service enters the building to the meter shall be exposed and accessible. 
(d)  The gas meter shall not be installed in a small, unventilated or confined space. 
(e)  A gas meter should not be placed where it will be subjected to damage, such as in driveways, public passages, halls, coal bins, etc., or where it will be subjected to excessive corrosion. 
(f)  Gas meters shall be located at a minimum of three (3) feet from any electric panel or meter, and a minimum of five (5) feet from a furnace or incinerator flue connector. It is desirable to avoid extreme temperatures and sudden changes in temperature. 
(g)  Pressure regulators supplied from medium or high pressure mains shall be installed outside of the building where practicable. 
(h)  The city and/or its designee reserves the right to enter upon the real estate and/or structure for the sole purpose of installing, maintaining, reading, removing, terminating or any other utility service function necessary dealing with the meter, lines, pipes or other city apparatuses used in providing utilities. In the event the landlord, tenant or occupant of the premises or real estate denies such entry, the city reserves the right to terminate the service and to estimate the charges for utilities provided. 
(Code 1968, § 52.08; Ord. No. 32-94, 7-12-94) 
Sec. 23-54. - Installation. 
(a)  All stop cocks shall be of the lubricated type. 
(b)  Where two (2) or more meters are manifolded at one location, a master cock controlling the gas supply to all meters must be provided in addition to the cocks controlling the supply to each meter. 
(c)  On multiple meter installations each meter stop shall be plainly marked by a metal tag installed by the gas fitter or plumber, designating the part of the building being supplied. 
(d)  The distance between any wall shall never be less than six (6) inches. On outside meter settings the bottom of meter shall be at least six (6) inches above finished grade. 
(e)  Meter settings must be plumb and level so that the meter will line up properly with the meter connections. 
(Code 1968, § 52.09) 
Sec. 23-55. - Use of gas lights. 
(a)  The use of natural gas purchased from the gas department for illumination purposes through gas lights or otherwise is hereby prohibited, except that the superintendent of the gas department may by written order and notice to customers allow the use of such lights when in his opinion there is sufficient natural gas available for the use of same. By written order and notice to the customers affected, the superintendent may, after such periods of allowed use, again prohibit the use of same for those periods which in his opinion a sufficient supply of natural gas should not be made available for such lights. 
(b)  The notice to the affected customers shall be satisfied by either a written notice delivered to them by the gas department or by notice thereof being published in the Henderson Gleaner for three (3) consecutive days. 
(c)  Any customer purchasing natural gas from the city for the hereinabove described purposes who continues to use natural gas for illumination purposes, at such times as such use is prohibited, shall be terminated as a customer of the gas department. 
(Ord. No. 12-77, §§ 1-3, 4-26-77; Ord. No. 7-82, 5-11-82) 
Sec. 23-56. - Additional residential gas customers. 
(a)  The superintendent of the gas department in his discretion, may approve and authorize new and additional residential gas customers, providing that the following conditions are satisfied: 
(1)  New gas lines may be added to the city's system to provide such service so long as such addition results in an equitable return to the city on its installation costs. 
(2)  There must be available from the city's gas supplier, a sufficient allocation of gas for such residential customers. 
(3)  If a person requesting gas service has that request approved by the superintendent of the gas department, such person must, within one hundred twenty (120) days of the approval, hook up to the city's gas system and utilize the natural gas furnished by the city. If such person fails to do so, the city may refuse to provide such service. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, residential customers shall also include apartment houses and any other facility which is to be used for residential purposes. 
(Ord. No. 39-78, §§ 1, 2, 11-21-78; Ord. No. 4-81, §§ 1, 2, 4-7-81) 
Secs. 23-57-23-60. - Reserved.

Sec. 23-61. - Franchise rights. 
(a)  Without a franchise granted by the city no person, firm or corporation ("person") shall have the right or privilege to: 
(1)  Erect, construct, operate or maintain or use any natural gas pipeline, plant or system or gasworks, or works within the city in order to sell or distribute or provide nonmunicipal natural gas to itself or any other user or consumer within the city; or 
(2)  Use the streets, alleys, or public grounds of the city for such purpose; or 
(3)  Interconnect any building, structure or facility of any kind to any natural gas pipeline or system other than to the natural gas system of the Henderson municipal gas department. 
(b)  No ordinance for the grant of a franchise for a natural gas distribution system as set forth in (a) shall be granted except under such terms and conditions as shall preserve the financial integrity of the Henderson municipal gas department and the amount of in lieu of tax payments received by the city from the Henderson municipal gas department. Such franchise ordinance shall require that any franchise holder shall pay to the city a franchise fee of fifteen (15) percent of gross receipts of the franchise holder's gas distribution system. Such gross receipts shall include the costs of operation and the costs of delivered natural gas. If the franchise holder is distributing to itself, the gross receipts shall include the cost of operation of the distribution system plus the delivered cost of the gas to be distributed. The franchise holder shall be required to make all of its records available to the city for the purpose of determining the franchise fee. If the franchise holder also is the owner of any facilities for the distribution or sale of natural gas, the delivered cost of the natural gas shall not be less than the average annual cost for the preceding calendar year of such delivered natural gas to be resold by the Henderson gas department (including all operating costs) for the purpose of computing the franchise fee. 
(c)  Unless a franchise has been given or granted it shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Erect, construct, operate or maintain or use any natural gas pipeline, plant or system or gasworks within the city in order to sell or distribute or provide nonmunicipal natural gas to itself or other consumer within the city; or, 
(2)  Use the streets, alleys, or public grounds of the city for such purpose; or 
(3)  Interconnect any building, structure or facility of any kind to any natural gas pipeline or system, other than to the natural gas system of the Henderson gas department. 
(d)  Any person seeking such a franchise shall (1) make application to the city manager on a form to be provided by the city, (2) provide notice of such an application to the public pursuant to KRS chapter 424, and (3) demonstrate at a public hearing that a substantial need exists for the construction and/or operation of gas distribution facilities that the proposed construction and/or operation is not contrary to the public interest. 
(e)  If any person constructs, operates or maintains any natural gas pipeline, plant of system or gasworks or works or sells or distributes any natural gas within the city, or makes any connections with gas contrary to the provisions of the foregoing; then in addition to any other remedies and measures provided by law, the city attorney or the city manager may commence an action in the name of and on behalf of the city for suitable and appropriate legal and equitable relief. 
(f)  Subsections (a)-(e) shall not apply to a person, firm, or corporation that connects its own natural gas pipelines and facilities located outside of the city to its own natural gas facilities located in the city that serve the end use requirements of such person, firm, or corporation. If property is annexed by the city, existing natural gas facilities located on such property shall not cause the owner of such facilities to become subject to this section. 
(Ord. No. 22-95, 5-23-95; Ord. No. 5-97, 4-8-97) 
Secs. 23-62-23-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - UTILITY POLES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Posting on poles, § 16-2. 

Sec. 23-76. - Permit for erection of poles-Required. 
    No person, excepting representatives of the city, shall erect any pole on any of the streets, alleys, sidewalks or other public places of the city, for electric light, telegraph, telephone, electric power or for any other purpose; or erect or string any wire or wires on any such pole erected on private property within the city; or change the lines, locations or height; or make an extension of any such lines or poles already erected or to be erected in the city, for any of such purposes, without first having obtained from the city engineer of the city a permit to do so. 
(Code 1968, § 92.40) 
Sec. 23-77. - Same-Application. 
    Any person desiring to obtain a permit under section 23-76 shall make application therefor, in writing, to the city engineer, which application shall state the number and kind of poles to be erected, the height of each above the ground, the location of each, and the purpose for which the same are to be used. Upon such application being made to the city engineer, he may proceed to act upon it, or he may refer the application to the street committee, which shall carefully examine same and report to the board of commissioners his recommendation. And the board may grant or refuse such privileges, or it may make such change or changes as it shall see fit in the terms thereof. 
(Code 1968, § 92.41) 
Sec. 23-78. - Poles to be straight. 
    Any pole erected by any person must be reasonably straight, of first-class material, neatly shaven and well-painted, and shall be so kept during the existence of such privilege. 
(Code 1968, § 92.42) 
Sec. 23-79. - Independent of trees. 
    All telegraph and telephone companies now granted or hereafter granted the privilege or franchise of erecting poles or support for their wires, to sustain their lines of communication from point to point in the city, are hereby required to erect the same independent of any and all shade trees or other trees planted by the city or any property owner, planting or sustaining such trees in the front of his property in the city. 
(Code 1968, § 92.43) 
Sec. 23-80. - Trees not to be injured. 
    No person shall injure, climb such trees or attach wires thereto, or saw or break the limbs thereof. 
(Code 1968, § 92.44) 
Sec. 23-81. - Rights and powers to remove and regulate poles. 
    The city engineer shall, at all times, reserve and have the right and power to cause any and all of such poles to be removed or replaced by other poles of a different character, or of a different height; to regulate the height above the ground at which such wires shall be strung; to require the removal of any poles or wires not in use; to require any and all of the poles to be removed and the wires laid underground, as the public good may require; and shall not be liable for any of the cost or damage occasioned by such changes, and it shall reserve the right and power to regulate and control same, and the streets, alleys and public ways over which same shall be constructed. Any such grant shall expire and become void, notwithstanding a consideration may have been paid therefor, unless a bona fide organization shall have taken place, and business been commenced thereunder in good faith, within one year from the date thereof, and no such privilege or permit shall be granted for a longer period than twenty (20) years. And the city engineer may impose other conditions and terms in addition to and not inconsistent with those herein enumerated. He shall also have the right and power to supervise and control the location of any of the poles, wires and appliances, in such manner as they may deem best; and to reserve to the city the right to use same for its fire alarm and police wires. Whenever it shall become necessary to change any of said poles for the improvement of any street, alley, sidewalk or other property, public or private, the city manager may order any such company to change same and if not done upon notice so to do, it may have same changed at the cost and expense of any such company; the time in which such change shall be made after receiving notice therefor, shall be specified in such grant or permit. 
(Code 1968, § 92.45) 
Sec. 23-82. - Indemnification of city. 
    Any person obtaining a permit under section 23-76 shall bind itself to protect, indemnify and hold harmless the city and the citizens thereof, from any damage or liability that may arise on account of any infringement by the person of the rights of any other person. It shall also protect and indemnify the city and the citizens thereof from all damage and liability by reason of the location of such poles, appliances and fixtures, or by reason of any other act of such company. 
(Code 1968, § 92.46) 
Sec. 23-83. - Application of article; imposition of tax. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to any person mentioned in section 23-76, who is now doing business within the limits of the city, as well as to those who may hereafter locate in the city; and the city reserves the right to impose such tax or taxes, franchise, license or otherwise, as it shall deem fit, and which is not contrary to the constitution and laws of this state. 
(Code 1968, § 92.47) 
Secs. 23-84-23-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RATES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 23-96. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Charges are the amounts in money due and payable for electric, gas, water, sewer, and storm water service rendered to customers of a municipal utility in the ordinary and regular course of business according to the rates fixed by the appropriate ordinance. 
    Collecting agent means any banking institution duly appointed and authorized to collect charges for any municipal utility. A collecting agent is not authorized to accept payment of any bill for charges after the date upon which the bill shall become due and payable. 
    Municipal utility means either the City of Henderson gas system; the Henderson municipal water, sewer or storm water system; or the Henderson municipal light and power system, and their duly appointed officers and employees responsible for billing and collection of charges. 
    Service charge means the amount in money assessed against an owner or tenant of premises served by any municipal utility for the cost of discontinuance of service and resumption due to the failure of the owner or tenant to pay the charges and penalty of any utility, and shall attach and be owing as of the date and time the charge is assessed and not when the service provided by the utility is actually discontinued or resumed. 
(Code 1968, § 50.01; Ord. No. 01-98, § 2, 1-27-98) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 23-97. - Rates and charges generally. 
    All rates and charges for municipal utilities shall be determined from time to time by the board of commissioners and kept on file in the clerk's office. 
(Code 1968, §§ 51.07, 51.08, 51.30, 52.20-52.26; Ord. No. 4-70, §§ 1-3, 1-20-70; Ord. No. 10-70, §§ 6, 7, 4-14-70; Ord. No. 31-70, § 1, 8-18-70; Ord. No. 47-70, 12-8-70; Ord. Sec. 23-98. - Water and sewer charges. 
(a)  Special rates: 
(1)  If the wastewater or other liquid wastes being discharged into the sewers from any building or premises is determined by HWU to contain unduly high concentrations of any substances which add to the operating cost of the sewer facilities of HWU, HWU may establish special rates or charges as to such class of building or premises, or HWU may require the owner or other interested party to specially treat such sewage, water or other liquid wastes before it is discharged into the sewers. 
(2)  HWU may establish rules and regulations regarding the use of the sewer facilities which may control the amount and characteristics of wastes permitted to be discharged therein where such quantities or characteristics may be injurious to the works or deleterious to their operation. 
(b)  Application for special classification. Whenever it is determined by HWU to be necessary to classify any commercial institutions or industries by reason of the unusual purpose for which water is used or the character of the wastewater or other liquid wastes discharged therefrom, or whenever the foregoing schedules or charges for any reason are not applicable, then HWU may establish special rates or other charges, and any person, being charged the foregoing rates and being dissatisfied therewith by reason of peculiar or unusual use or occupancy of any premises and consequently alleging peculiar or unusual uses of water, may file application with HWU for special classification, rates or charges. 
(c)  Authority to revise rates. The rates or charges shall be revised from time to time as may be necessary in order that the city may comply with the covenants and undertakings securing the water and sewer revenue bonds of the city. 
(d)  No free sewer service. No free use of the services and facilities of the sanitary sewers shall be granted or permitted to any sewer user, excepting the city itself. 
(e)  Provision of water and wastewater service, rates and charges outside city. There shall be monthly rates and charges for water and/or wastewater services rendered by HWU to customers and users outside the corporate limits of the city. The city owes no obligation to make water or wastewater service available to property located outside its corporate limits, and does not offer water or wastewater services to such property except under the following conditions: 
(1)  Where such property is adjacent to or within reasonable distance of a water or wastewater main or line in the service area of HWU's water or wastewater plants, the owner of such property may make written application to the water and sewer commission for the privilege of connecting to such water and/or wastewater main or line. The application shall include a properly executed and notarized form consenting to annexation and the provision of water and/or wastewater service shall be conditioned on the execution of a deed restriction for the property to be served not to oppose annexation. If, in the sole discretion of the water and sewer commission (each case to be judged on its own merits) such connection can be accommodated without exceeding the capacity of the main or line in question or causing other problems in the distribution, collection, or treatment systems and will be beneficial to the public health and welfare of the area, the water and sewer commission may approve the application subject to formal acceptance by the board of commissioners. 
(2)  Where an existing private or publicly owned wastewater system is to be taken over in whole or in part by HWU, such system can be accepted following written application to and approval by the water and sewer commission and formal acceptance by the board of commissioners. 
(3)  Where an existing private or publicly owned wastewater system desires to contract with HWU for wastewater services such contractual arrangements can be accepted following written application to and approval by the water and sewer commission and formal acceptance by the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1968, §§ 51.09-51.12, 51.19, 51.31; Ord. No. 06-00, § 2, 1-25-00; Ord. No. 07-06, 4-11-06; Ord. No. 4-16, 2-23-16) 
Sec. 23-99. - Charges billed to owner of premises; deposit; exception. 
(a)  The charges of any municipal utility shall be billed to the owner of the premises except as provided herein. Upon application by the tenant of any premises, who is not the owner filed with the respective utility, accompanied by an appropriate security or deposit in cash in an amount approved by the utility, the bill for charges may be rendered to the tenant. 
(b)  Interest will accrue on all deposits at the rate prescribed by KRS 278.460 beginning on the date of the deposit. Interest accrued will be refunded to the customer or credited to the customer's bill on an annual basis. If interest is paid or credited to the customer's bill prior to twelve (12) months from the date of deposit or the last interest payment date, the payment or credit shall be on a prorated basis. Such interest shall not be compounded. 
(c)  All interest accruing on such cash deposits shall be paid annually at the conclusion of the fiscal year of the city or the utility commission, as the case may be, by crediting to and deducting from the depositor's next succeeding utility bill a sum equal to such unpaid accrued interest. The first such payment of all unpaid accrued interest by credit shall be made at the conclusion of the 1983-84 fiscal year and annually thereafter. 
(d)  The cash deposit of depositors voluntarily terminating utility service shall be refunded with accrued interest, computed in the manner stated herein, in cash, to the extent such deposit and accrued interest exceeds the final unpaid utility bill of such depositor. 
(e)  Notwithstanding the requirement of subsection (a), a deposit will not be required for real estate being sold under a contract of sale or under a deed with a purchase money lien retained by the seller, if both the seller and buyer sign documents required by the city that will bind both the seller and buyer to the city for the payment for all gas and/or electricity used. 
(f)  In lieu of the requirement of subsection (a), all residential or commercial tenants may post with the city a surety bond, to be approved by the director of finance. 
(g)  In lieu of the surety bond required by subsection (f), an owner of real estate who is a user of city utilities and who has not been on the "cut off" list since he or she has been such a user or for the past twenty-four (24) months, may sign as a guarantor for a residential tenant. Such guaranty agreement with the city, shall provide for and shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  If the residential tenant shall fail to pay his or her utility charges within ten (10) days from the date of issuance and mailing of the bill, such bill shall then be mailed to the guarantor. If the guarantor fails to pay said bill within six (6) days from the date of said issuance and mailing to him or her, the service provided by the appropriate utility shall be discontinued in due course to the premises of both the residential tenant and the guarantor and said charges shall be assessed against the guarantor. Service shall not be resumed to the premises of either the residential tenant or the guarantor, where such service has been discontinued for said nonpayment, until all charges, penalty and service charges have been paid in full. 
(2)  If the guarantor ceases to become a user of city utilities, or gives to the city written notice that he or she wants to be removed as guarantor, his or her guaranty agreement with the city shall be terminated within ten (10) days after actual notice thereof is given to tenant. Tenant shall, within said ten-day period, make the required cash deposit, or post the appropriate surety bond, or have a qualified guarantor execute another guaranty agreement on his or her behalf. 
(3)  No person may sign as a guarantor for more than three (3) residential tenant users of city utilities, except with the written consent of the city manager. 
(4)  The provisions of this subsection shall be applied retroactively. Every residential tenant who has previously made the required cash deposit shall, upon the execution of the guaranty agreement required by this subsection, be reimbursed in the amount of such deposit. 
(5)  The city manager may waive the requirement for a utility security deposit by a tenant who is not the owner of the premises when the tenant is financially unable to provide the deposit as a result of emergency conditions beyond the control of the tenant. 
(h)  City may transfer delinquent read out bills of a customer to any other account under the customer's name or Social Security number. 
(Code 1968, §§ 50.02, 51.15, 52.20; Ord. No. 35-80, 9-23-80; Ord. No. 32-82, 9-28-82; Ord. No. 33-82, 9-28-82; Ord. No. 24-83, 10-25-83; Ord. No. 33-83, 12-13-83; Ord. No. 32-94, 7-12-94; Ord. No. 18-05, 9-13-05; Ord. No. 20-12, 7-10-12) 
Sec. 23-99.1. - Deposit for residential gas customers. 
(a)  All residential and commercial gas customers who are not owners of real estate shall post a deposit of an amount equal to one-sixth ( 1/6 ) of the most recent annual gas bill to the premises. 
(b)  This section shall be applied retroactively. Any such customer who has deposited with the city a sum more than what his deposit would now be, under subsection (a), shall, upon request, have said excess sum deducted from the following month's gas bill. 
(c)  The deposit to be made under subsection (a) shall be to the nearest and highest ten dollar ($10.00) figure. 
(d)  A cash deposit will be required from property owning customers who declare bankruptcy pursuant to federal law equivalent to the amounts required as deposits from customers who are not owners of real estate as set forth in subsection (a) above. The city will discontinue service to any customer upon failure to make the required deposit after a ten-day written notice has been given to said customer. Said deposit may be refunded at the discretion of the finance director, or his designee, following a determination that satisfactory financial arrangements have been made and that the security is no longer required. 
(Ord. No. 27-83, 10-25-83; Ord. No. 33-83, 12-13-82; Ord. No. 16-88, 4-26-88; Ord. No. 32-94, 7-12-94) 
Sec. 23-100. - Due date. 
(a)  The bill for charges of any municipal utility shall be mailed to the owner or tenant of the premises, as the case may be, on a monthly basis and shall have written thereon a date upon which the bills are due and payable. The date upon which the bills are due and payable for residential customers shall not be less than ten (10) days from the date of the issuance and mailing of the bill. The date upon which the bills are due and payable for commercial and industrial customers shall be on the last day of the month, and if such day falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or holiday, the due date shall be on the city's next business day. 
(b)  The city manager or his designee may, in his absolute discretion, enter into written agreements with customers of the gas department to allow such customers to pay their gas bills in monthly installments. Such payments would be made in eleven (11) equal monthly installments, beginning with the due date of the June bill of each year, with the balance being due on the twelfth monthly payment. Arrangements for such billing shall be made by customers before the June billing of each year, except that new customers being provided with service shall also have the opportunity to make installment payments, with the approval of the city manager or his designee. 
(c)  The city manager or his designee may, in his absolute discretion, enter into written agreements with customers of the electric department to allow such customers to pay their electric bills in monthly installments. Such payments would be made in eleven (11) equal monthly installments, beginning with the due date of the October bill of each year, with the balance being due on the twelfth monthly payment. Arrangements for such billing shall be made by customers before the October billing of each year, except that new customers being provided with service shall also have the opportunity to make installment payments, with the approval of the city manager or his designee. 
(Code 1968, § 50.03; Ord. No. 33-82, 9-28-82; Ord. No. 32-94, 7-12-94; Ord. No. 09-06, 5-9-06) 
Sec. 23-101. - Penalty for late payment. 
    In the event payment of any utility bill is not received by a collector or the various city collection offices prior to the close of business on the date that the bill shall become due and payable, a penalty of five (5) percent of the charges shall attach thereto and be payable in addition to the amount of such charges and the bill shall be deemed delinquent. Customers may appeal the penalty assessed to their account if they meet all of the following requirements: 
(1)  They must have paid their prior twelve (12) utility bills on time. 
(2)  They must not owe any delinquent property taxes, liens, or other debt to the city or its agencies. 
(3)  The individual requesting the release must also be the same person that signs the checks that are used to pay the utility bill. The appeal should be made to the city manager or his designated representative, which decision shall be final. 
(Code 1968, §§ 50.04, 51.18; Ord. No. 09-06, 5-9-06) 
Sec. 23-102. - Notice of discontinuance of service. 
    On the day that the bill of any municipal utility shall have become delinquent, the utility shall mail a notice to the delinquent owner or tenant, as the case may be. This notice shall contain the address of the premises, the amount of the delinquent charges and penalty and on those accounts in excess of thirty dollars ($30.00) the due date upon which the service shall be discontinued unless payment shall be sooner received at the various city collection offices, and the date shall not be less than five (5) days after the mailing of the notice. 
(Code 1968, §§ 50.05, 51.18; Ord. No. 09-06, 5-9-06) 
Sec. 23-103. - Discontinuance of service and charges. 
(a)  If any charges and penalties thereon of any municipal utility in excess of thirty dollars ($30.00) have not been paid by 9:00 a.m. on the sixth day following the mailing of the notice of discontinuance, the service provided by the appropriate utility shall be discontinued in due course and charges shall be assessed against the delinquent owner or tenant as determined from time to time by the board of commissioners and kept on file in the clerk's office. These charges shall not apply to accounts that are guaranteed by vouchers submitted prior to the cutoff date from community service agencies as determined by the city manager or his designee. 
(b)  Services shall not be resumed to the premises where such service has been discontinued for nonpayment until all charges, penalty and service charge have been paid in full. Any person who failed to make such payments shall not be provided services at any other premises which he may later occupy until all such past charges, penalty and service charges have been paid in full. There shall be an additional service charge of twenty five dollars ($25.00); fifty dollars ($50.00) for any service calls after 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday, weekends and holidays if service has been discontinued for nonpayment. 
(c)  For natural gas service calls, there shall be a charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for services performed, including gas pilot lighting, during normal business hours; and a charge of thirty-seven dollars fifty cents ($37.50) if such services, including gas pilot lighting, are performed after 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday, weekends and holidays. 
(d)  The deposit made with any municipal utility by a tenant as set out in section 23-99 may be forfeited and applied in payment of any amounts due and owing by virtue of the terms of this article. 
(Code 1968, §§ 50.06, 51.18; Ord. No. 23-82, 7-27-82; Ord. No. 33-83, 12-18-83; Ord. No. 17-88, 4-26-88; Ord. No. 32-94, 7-12-94; Ord. No. 09-06, 5-9-06) 
Sec. 23-104. - Discontinuance of service inapplicable. 
    If an owner or tenant of premises shall notify the appropriate municipal utility in writing that the premises served by the utility shall be vacant for a period of time for any reason, the service charge and discontinuance of service provided in section 23-103 shall not be applicable until the following monthly period. 
(Code 1968, § 50.07) 
Sec. 23-105. - Dishonored checks. 
    If a check is received in payment for charges and penalty prior to the time provided for the discontinuance of service as set out in section 23-103, and the check is not honored by the bank upon which it is drawn, the appropriate municipal utility shall discontinue the service forthwith on the date set for discontinuance or upon receipt of notice of dishonor, if the date has passed, and a service charge will be assessed as of the date set for discontinuance of service. 
(Code 1968, § 50.08) 
Sec. 23-106. - Collection of bills. 
(a)  Whether or not any premises is disconnected because of delinquency, the city attorney is hereby authorized and directed to enforce and collect the amount of any bills remaining delinquent for thirty (30) days (including the penalty, interest, disconnection charge and court costs) by suit in any court competent jurisdiction. 
(b)  The city manager or his designated representative may enter into a written and signed agreement with current customers who are not able to pay their utility bill on a timely basis. The agreement shall include language that the customer must pay any current bill plus a reasonable portion of the prior debt on an installment basis. The agreements shall not exceed twelve (12) months. If the customer fails to meet the terms in the agreement, service shall be discontinued. 
(c)  The city manager or his designated representative may enter into a written and signed agreement with prior customers that wish to establish service again but owe an old debt. The agreement shall include language that the customer must pay any current bill as due, plus the prior debt on an installment basis. The agreements shall not exceed twelve (12) months. If the customer fails to meet the terms in the agreement, service shall be discontinued. 
(Code 1968, § 51.14; Ord. No. 09-06, 5-9-06) 
Sec. 23-107. - Combined utility billing. 
    Nothing contained in any of the sections of this article shall prevent the joint or combined utility billing by all of the municipal utilities. 
(Code 1968, §§ 50.09, 50.10) 
Sec. 23-108. - Fee for collection of utility bills. 
    The fee for the collection of utility bills of the city by the collecting agents shall be determined from time to time by the board of commissioners and kept on file in the clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 23-69, 6-25-69) 
Sec. 23-109. - Lien for unpaid utility charges. 
(a)  The city shall have a lien against real property equal to value of any unpaid utility bill charged to the said real property for utility services. The lien shall be filed in the office of the Henderson County court clerk, against the said real estate where services are/or were provided or discontinued, shall be assessed against the delinquent owner of the said real estate, shall bear interest at eight (8) percent per annum from date of filing, and shall be superior to all liens recorded. 
(b)  Services shall not be reconnected and/or restored to the real property or to any improvements thereon, until the said lien is satisfied. 
(c)  If the real property subject to this lien is sold and the delinquent utility bill is not satisfied, the lien for utility services shall be created as a special assessment and shall have priority to all other liens regardless of priority in time. 
(d)  The city may enforce collection of delinquent utility charges pursuant to section 23-106, or by proceedings to enforce the lien created hereunder. 
(e)  The creation of this utility lien and the underlying provisions for collection and enforcement of same shall be retroactive in application and applicable to all real property owners that have deficient utility accounts with the city or the commission against the said property. 
(Ord. No. 43-90, § 1, 8-28-90) 
Sec. 23-110. - Amounts owed for incidental utility services and goods may be added to utility bills. 
(a)  Any charges remaining unpaid for a period of thirty (30) days past the date of invoice of incidental services and goods furnished to a utility customer by any of the city's utilities, plus any penalty and interest owned thereon, may be included in and added to a customer's regular utility bill, and shall be due and payable along with such regular bill and subject to all provisions applicable to the payment or nonpayment and collection of said regular utility bill. 
(b)  Such incidental services and goods shall include, but not be limited to, the following: relocating gas meters; running gas service lines; damage repair of gas lines; lighting pilot lights; sales of gas grills and parts; gas pipe fittings; sewer service surcharges; industrial monitoring costs; miscellaneous temporary water consumption; repairs for damages to public water/sewer services; unauthorized use of water from meters or fire hydrants; sewer tap locates; and any other types of incidental utility services or goods provided to a utility customer. 
(Ord. No. 8-97, 3-25-97) 
Sec. 23-111. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 01-98, § 3, adopted Jan. 27, 1998, repealed in their entirety the provisions of § 23-111 which pertained to the storm water administration/operation fee and derived from Ord. No. 24-97, adopted July 22, 1997. 
Secs. 23-112-23-118. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - UTILITY COMMISSION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; boards, commissions and committees generally, § 2-116 et seq. 
State Law reference- Utilities in cities, KRS Ch. 96; power of third class city to furnish utility services, KRS 96.170; utility commission, KRS 96. 530. 

Sec. 23-119. - Established. 
    The municipal light and power system of the city shall be operated, managed and controlled by a commission of five (5) members designated as the City of Henderson Utility Commission." 
(Code 19 68, § 36.40; Ord. No. 50-00, 1-9-01) 
Sec. 23-120. - Appointment of members; removal; employees. 
    The appointment from time to time of the members of the utility commission and their employment of personnel to carry on the operation of the municipally owned electric light and power system shall be in conformity with the provisions of KRS 96.530. A member of the utility commission may be removed for cause after hearing by the majority vote of all the city's board of commissioners. 
(Code 1968, § 36.42; Ord. No. 30-10, 12-16-10) 
Sec. 23-121. - Bonds. 
    Each utility commissioner shall execute a bond which shall be approved by the board of commissioners. Corporate surety shall be provided by a surety company qualified to do business in the state, and the premiums on the surety bonds shall constitute a part of the expense of operating the electric light and power system. 
(Code 1968, § 36.43) 
Sec. 23-122. - Powers and duties. 
    The utility commission shall have all the powers and duties prescribed by KRS 96.530. 
(Code 1968, § 36.41) 
Sec. 23-123. - Administration of light and power department. 
    The light and power department shall be administered by the city utility commission in the manner provided by KRS 96.530. The utility commission shall not be under the civil service system. The positions of employment within the department and the compensation thereof shall be regulated by the city utility commission. All regular positions of full-time employment in the department are classified as within and subject to the civil service system, and vacancies therein shall be filled by appointment of the board of commissioners upon recommendation of the city utility commission. Beginning on July 13, 1990, the utility commission may fill all regular positions of full-time employment, and all vacancies therein, without those employees being classified as within and subject to the civil service system, and without submitting the names of those employees to the board of commissioners for appointment. 
(Code 1968, § 36.44; Ord. No. 02-05, 3-22-05) 
Secs. 23-124-23-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TELEPHONE SERVICE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 23-131-23-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - 911 EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SERVICE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 47-86, adopted Nov. 11, 1986, did not specifically amend the Code, hence inclusion of §§ 1-4 as Div. 2, §§ 23-141-23-144 was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 23-141. - Interlocal agreements adopted. 
    The resolution of the board of commissioners of the City of Henderson, dated April 8, 1980, authorizing the mayor to enter into the interlocal agreement establishing the Henderson Emergency Communications Center and the interlocal agreement establishing the Henderson Emergency Communications Center and the use of the "911" emergency communications number, is hereby ratified and confirmed and adopted as a part of this division as if set forth herein, copies of which are attached hereto as Exhibit A and B respectively, which are attached hereto for all purposes. 
(Ord. No. 47-86, § 1, 11-11-86) 
Editor's note- Exhibits A and B, the interlocal agreements concerning the 911 emergency communication system, referenced in § 23-141 above, have not been set out at length herein but are on file and available for inspection in the offices of the city. 
Sec. 23-142. - Agreement. 
(a)  The City of Henderson, by and through the mayor, is authorized to enter into an agreement along with the Henderson County Fiscal Court in compliance with the interlocal agreement previously establishing the Henderson Emergency Communications Center and with the phone company to provide for the construction, implementation and ongoing maintenance of the enhanced "911" service and reratifying any such agreement as may be necessary with the phone company to continue the maintenance of the "911" service previously established by the interlocal agreement establishing the Henderson Emergency Communications Center. Said agreement shall be for a period of from the date of the filing of said agreement until March 31, 1988, and for one-year periods thereafter, and shall be automatically renewable upon the same terms and conditions unless prior to thirty (30) days of the close of the said period or any following twelve-month period after the original term, either party notifies the other of its intention to modify and/or terminate said agreement. This initial term is for a period of in excess of one (1) year in order to allow the ending date to be in compliance on a yearly basis with the original term as established in the Henderson Emergency Communications Center Interlocal Agreement, which term originally commenced on April 1, 1980, and ran to March 31, 1981, and was automatically renewable for a twelve-month period unless terminated by either party. 
(b)  The agreement shall reflect the installation costs and the current tariffed recurring charges for enhanced 911 service charged during the contract period. 
(Ord. No. 47-86, § 2, 11-11-86) 
Sec. 23-143. - "911" fee. 
(a)  There is hereby established a "911" fee of one dollar fifty cents ($1.50) per month for each exchange telephone subscriber and such fee shall increase automatically by the sum of twenty-five cents ($0.25) on March 1 of each year for four (4) consecutive years beginning on March 1, 2008, which is levied as a special tax, license, and/or fee to be paid by each exchange telephone subscriber in Henderson County E911 service area, TAR code 851, on an individual exchange line basis limited to a maximum of twenty-five (25) exchange lines per account. 
(b)  Pursuant to an existing agreement, the local exchange telephone company shall collect the "911" fee from the subscriber and remit said fee to the city according to its terms and state law. 
(Ord. No. 47-86, § 3, 11-11-86; Ord. No. 26-92, § 1, 7-28-92; Ord. No. 25-00, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 04-07, 2-27-07) 
Sec. 23-144. - "911" advisory board. 
(a)  There is hereby established a Henderson County "911" Advisory Board which shall be comprised of the same members of the advisory board for the Henderson Emergency Communications Center as set forth in the interlocal agreement dated April 8, 1980, and which shall be comprised of the following individuals: 
(1)  Henderson City Police Chief or designee. 
(2)  Henderson City Fire Chief or designee. 
(3)  Henderson County Sheriff or designee. 
(4)  Representative of all Henderson County Volunteer Fire Departments as appointed by the Henderson County Chief's Association or designee. 
(5)  Operations director of the Henderson Ambulance Service or designee. 
(6)  The working supervisor of the Henderson Emergency Communications Center. 
(7)  The Henderson County Disaster and Emergency Service Director. If this position is unfilled or vacant, the board shall be comprised of only seven (7) members. 
(8)  A representative of the Henderson County Fiscal Court or designee. 
(b)  Said board shall meet quarterly and the chairman shall call special meetings upon written notice delivered to the members at least seven (7) days prior to any special meeting. 
(c)  The board shall continuously monitor the procedures established for the operation of the "911" system and make recommendations to the board of commissioners of the City of Henderson and to the Henderson County Fiscal Court for effective implementation of the emergency telephone system. 
(d)  Appointed representatives shall serve at the pleasure of the appointing authority. 
(Ord. No. 47-86, § 4, 11-11-86) 
Secs. 23-145-23-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - TRENCHLESS CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 23-161. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Horizontal directional drilling is a steerable, trenchless method of installing underground pipes, conduits and cables in a shallow arc along a prescribed bore path by using a surface-launched drilling rig, with minimal impact to the surrounding area. 
    Jacking and boring is a method of pipe installation utilizing excavated pits, where pipe is assembled in the launching pit, and pushed through the ground to the receiving pit. This method often includes installation of a carrier pipe or casing, with a conventional transmission pipe inside the casing. 
    Trenchless construction is a collection of methods, materials, and equipment used for the installation of new or replacement underground pipes, conduits and cables with minimal disruption to surface traffic, business, and other activities and requiring minimal excavation and no continuous trenches. It includes horizontal directional drilling, and jacking and boring. 
(Ord. No. 28-14, Exh. A, 8-26-14) 
Sec. 23-162. - Permits. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall install a utility facility, pipe, or cable using trenchless construction technology on any of the streets, rights-of-way, alleys, sidewalks, public utility easements or other public places of the city, either for electric power, natural gas, fiber optic lines, cable television, telephone, potable water, sanitary sewer or stormwater pipe, or for any other purpose; or make an extension of any such utility or facility already installed or to be installed in the city; without first having obtained a permit to do so from the city. Permits shall be issued at no cost. 
(Ord. No. 28-14, Exh. A, 8-26-14) 
Sec. 23-163. - Contents of permit application. 
    Permit applications shall be made of forms provided by the city and shall contain: 
(1)  Name, address and twenty-four-hour contact information of the owner of the facility to be installed, and the installation contractor, if different from the owner; 
(2)  A description of the type of trenchless technology to be used in the installation; 
(3)  A site plan detailing: the area where facilities will be installed; existing known utilities in the area covered, including ownership information; locations of launching and receiving pits, pipe laydown and storage areas; 
(4)  Details (size, type, materials of construction, etc.) of the pipe, casing, conduit or wire to be installed; 
(5)  Details of any traffic control signs, barricades or safety devices required at the location of the installation; 
(6)  Proof of insurance and bonding. 
(Ord. No. 28-14, Exh. A, 8-26-14) 
Sec. 23-164. - Installation standards. 
(a)  New facilities must maintain appropriate horizontal and vertical clearance from existing pipes, cables and conduits, and shall not be installed parallel and atop or below existing facilities. 
(b)  At crossings, new facilities shall be separated from existing utilities by a minimum distance of six (6) inches. 
(c)  Where directional drilling or boring crosses a city street or sidewalk, the installer shall monitor the surface condition of said street or sidewalk, and shall report any change in elevation, cracking, or evidence of other damage to the city. 
(d)  All new underground facilities shall include a means to accurately identify and locate the underground facilities from the surface. 
(e)  Excavations for launching or receiving pits must meet the requirements of Chapter 7, Article VI, Erosion and Sediment Control and Cleaning of Streets. 
(f)  Drilling fluids and spoil materials must be contained and disposed of appropriately, and any fluids or spoil spilled onto the ground or on street surfaces shall be properly cleaned up and disposed of. Washing of spilled fluids or spoil into streets, gutters, storm drains or ditches is prohibited. 
(g)  Existing city-owned sanitary or storm sewers crossed or paralleled by the installation shall be inspected by video to insure that no cross-bores occur during installation. 
(h)  No work shall be performed prior to contacting Kentucky 811 and existing underground utilities being located and marked. Installer is responsible for contacting utilities that do not subscribe to Kentucky 811. 
(Ord. No. 28-14, Exh. A, 8-26-14) 
Sec. 23-165. - Responsibility for cost; replacing, rebuilding after excavation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation installing utility facilities using trenchless construction shall be responsible for the cost of, and after having completed such work, be required to replace and rebuild that portion of the streets, public alleys, sidewalks, or city-owned utility facilities damaged or removed by such installation, in such a manner that it will be in a condition as good as it was prior to the issuing of permit for such work. This responsibility includes city-incurred costs for response to and repair of any damage to facilities, as well as the costs of any water or natural gas lost due to damage caused by the person, firm or corporation performing the installation. 
(Ord. No. 28-14, Exh. A, 8-26-14) 
Sec. 23-166. - Indemnification of city. 
    Any person, firm or corporation obtaining a permit under section 23-162 shall bind itself to protect, indemnify and hold harmless the city, its elected officials, its appointed officials, its employees, and the citizens thereof, from any damage or liability that may arise on account of any infringement by the person, firm or corporation on the rights of any other person, firm or corporation. It shall also protect and indemnify the city, its elected officials, its appointed officials, its employees and the citizens thereof from all damage and liability, including all costs, and attorneys' fees, by reason of any other act of such person, firm or corporation. 
(Ord. No. 28-14, Exh. A, 8-26-14) 
ARTICLE IX. - TELECOMMUNICATIONS 

Sec. 23-167. - [Legislative finding.] 
    It is hereby declared as a legislative finding that the rights-of-way within the City of Henderson, Kentucky: 
(1)  Are a unique and physically limited resource; 
(2)  Are critical to the travel and transport of persons and property in the City of Henderson, Kentucky; 
(3)  Are intended for public uses and must be managed and controlled consistent with that intent; 
(4)  Can be partially occupied by the facilities of utilities and public service entities, to the enhancement of the health, welfare, and general economic well being of the City of Henderson, Kentucky and its citizens; and 
(5)  Should be subject to specific additional regulations imposed in a competitively neutral and non-discretionary manner as established by this subchapter to ensure coordination of users, maximize available space, and facilitate entry of a maximum number of providers of communications and other services in the public interest. 
(Ord. No. 07-15, 4-28-15) 
Sec. 23-168. - [Franchise created.] 
    There is hereby created a non-exclusive franchise granting to the grantee thereof whose bid may be accepted, the discretionary right to construct, erect, operate and maintain upon, through, along, under and over the streets, alleys, avenues, public roads, highways, bridges, viaducts, sidewalks and other public ways of Henderson, Kentucky, a telecommunications system embracing underground conduits, manholes, cables, boxes, wires, fixtures, fiber, electrical conductors and other apparatus, equipment and facilities necessary, essential, used or useful to and in the operation of a telecommunications system.
